The Monroe County, Ohio Scrapbook

Volume: A

1834-2005

by Lena Kahrig Pettit

 

Abbott, Joseph Franklin

            Born: January 18, 1879, in Monroe County, Ohio. Died: August 2, 1979, in Clermont County, Ohio. Burial: August 5, 1979, Clermont County, Ohio. Father: Isaac Watt Abbott. Mother: Martha Jane DeMaris. Married: Anna Silvia Bell on January 19, 1908. Source: Monroe County death and marriage records.

 

Abbott, Lottie           

            Born: July 8, 1872. Died: November 1972. Residence: Beallsville, Ohio.

Source: Monroe County death records.

               

Aberick, Samuel F and Phebe Jane Ward          

            Married: February 26, 1875. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Aberegg, Harold

            Harold Aberegg, 73, of Jacksonburg, West Virginia died Thursday, May 7, 1987, in the Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville, West Virginia. He was a retired employee of Consolidated Gas Supply Corporation, Hastings, West Virginia and a retired machinist for Ormet Corporation, Hannibal, Ohio. He was a member of the New Martinsville Church of Christ. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Birtie E. Palmer Aberegg in 1979; and a brother. Surviving are his wife, Reda Minger Bartrug Aberegg; a son Terry of Reader, West Virginia; three stepsons, Jack Pegg of Glenville, West Virginia, Richard L. Bartrug, Jr. of Wilmington, North Carolina and Daniel R. Bartrug of Chicago; two daughters, Betty Jo Gehart of Fairfax, Virginia and Joan Rice of Marietta, Georgia; two sisters, Hazel Clark of Midland, Texas and Louise Brown of Jacksonburg; four grandchildren; two great-grandchildren. Friends received at Palmer Funeral Home in Pine Grove where services were held. Interment in Northview Cemetery, New Martinsville, West Virginia.

Source: Wetzel County Message Board, West Virginia, Published: May 1987.

 

Aberigg, John H. and Priscilla P. Brock

            John H. Aberigg, age 24, of Belmont County, Ohio. Parents: James and P. Pall Aberigg. Married on October 3, 1900, to Priscilla P. Brock, age 22, of Monroe County, Ohio. Daughter of: Joseph R. and Barbara E. Headley Brock.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Aberigg, N. T. and Lillie B. Potts   

            N. T. Aberigg, age 24 of Monroe County. Parents: Samuel and Phebe J. Ward Aberigg. Married: February 9, 1901, to Lillie B. Potts, age 21 of Monroe County. Daughter of: D. F. and Sarah Hoskinson Aberigg.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

Father: John Abersold. Mother: Mary Ann Leech.

Abersold, Emitt George

            Emitt George was born October 9, 1875, Adams Township, Monroe County, Ohio. Father: John Abersold. Mother: Mary Ann Leech.

 

Abersold, John H. and Mary Mack           

            John H. Abersold, farmer, and Mary Mack were married May 28, 1895.

Johns fathers birthplace: Switzerland. Mothers birthplace: Switzerland.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Abersold, Rose

            Rose Abersold was born: December 16, 1893, Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio. Died: November 22, 1971. Father: Samuel Franklin Abersold.

Mother: Ozora Anna Ross.

 

Abersold, Samuel Franklin and Ozora Anna Ross

            Married: May 20, 1893, Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio. Samuel was born: May 1859, Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio. Died:1938, Moundsville, Marshall County, West Virginia. Ozora Anna Ross was born: January 23, 1871, Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio. Died: August 22, 1935, Clarington, Monroe County, Ohio.

 

Abersold, William H. and Ellen Mellott     

            William H. Abersold and Ellen V. Mellott, age 17, were married February 17, 1884. Source: Monroe County marriage records. William H. Abersold died: January 1, 1930, Beallsville, Ohio, Monroe County, Ohio. Born: September 10, 1854. Source: Monroe County death records.

Volume number: 6202. Certificate number: 4710.

 

Abicht, Denver F.    

            Denver F. Abicht, 73, of Cisler Drive, Marietta, Ohio, died at 10:47 p.m. Monday (February 2, 2004) at Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born May 15, 1930, in Marietta to Carl and Bernice Dixon Abicht. He was a 1948 graduate of Marietta High School and was employed at Hall Brothers Inc. from 1946 to 1948. He served United States Air Force from 1948 until 1952, during the Korean conflict and held the rank of staff sergeant when he was honorably discharged. He was later employed at the Brickwede Furniture Company from 1952 to 1954. He later moved to Elyria, Ohio, where he worked at the Pfaudler Factory as a drill press operator.  After returning to Marietta, he was again employed by Hall Brothers Inc. from 1955 to 1965 as service parts manager. From 1965 to 1979 he was business coordinator at Marietta Apparatus Company. He attended Ohio State University and became an industrial electricity instructor at Washington County Vocational School from 1979 until his retirement in 1992. He was a member of the Sixth and Washington Streets Church of Christ in Marietta. He was a life member of Washington County 40/8, Washington County Voiture 389, at Highland Park, and held all offices during his 31 years of service. His summer pastime was mowing the grass at Highland Park. He was a member of American Legion Post 64 of Marietta and was past president of the Marietta Firefighters Association. He had also been a member of the Washington County Fish and Game Club. He loved to travel, especially during his retirement. He is survived by his wife, Winona J. Gatten Abicht, whom he married on December 31, 1950; one son, Denver D. Abicht and his wife, Holly, of Marietta; one daughter, Cathy B. Abicht of Janesville, Wisconsin; one foster daughter, Gail Lucas of Parkersburg; one granddaughter, Erica J. Abicht DeFord and one great-granddaughter, Trinity R. Abicht of Marietta; one sister, Betty Jean Abicht Schau of Marietta; four step-grandsons, Mitch, Donnie, Dustin and Dylan; three great-grandchildren; and several nephews and nieces. He was preceded in death by his parents; one sister, Clara Abicht Montagnese; and one daughter-in-law, Debra Menke Abicht. Memorial services are at 2:30 p.m. Saturday at McClure-Schafer-Lankford Funeral Home in Marietta with Roger Rush officiating. Military rites by American Legion Post 64 will follow. The family will be present to meet friends for one hour prior to the services.

Source: The Marietta Times, Wednesday, February 4, 2004.

 

Ables, Alice (nee DeVoe)

            Alice DeVoe was one of four in the graduating class of 1926 at Lewisville High School. She died in 1993. Source: Lewisville, Ohio high school news.

 

Abmyer, Alvin Benge

            Alvin Benge Abmyer was born: September 25, 1875, Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio. Father: Isaac Abmyer. Mother: Harriet A. Hardesty.

 

Abmyer, Harold Landis

            Born: April 20, 1920, Beallsville, Ohio. Father: Cliffton Abmyer. Mother: Noma V. Landis. Source: Monroe County birth records.

 

1916

DEATH

Name:   Isaac Abmyer

Source:  The Spirit of Democracy

Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 15, 1916

 Isaac Abmyer, aged 83 years, a  former resident of Summerfield, was instantly killed at Zanesville last week when he was struck by an Ohio electric interurban car  just west of the State Street bridge in that city. 

 

Abmyer, Mary Ruth

            Born: January 26, 1919, Beallsville, Ohio. Father: Clifton C. Abmyer. Mother: Noma V. Landis. Source: Monroe County birth records.

 

Abmyre, Clara and L. D. Wire       

            Married: July 2, 1879. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Abmyre, Hattie Olive and G. O. Casner   

            Married: December 27, 1888. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Abraham, Coulter and Elizabeth Rush     

            Married: December 19, 1872. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Abrigg, Almeta

            Born and died: June 24, 1924, (stillborn) Clarington. Volume number: 83. Certificate number: 2451. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Abrigg, Audrey Mae Schaefer                   

            Mrs. Audrey Mae Schaefer, wife of Chester Schaefer, and a resident of Hannibal, Ohio, passed away in the Wheeling Hospital, Wednesday, February 15, at 6:00 A.M. She was born at Sardis, Route 2, November 10, 1923, the daughter of Edwin and Amelia Abrigg. She was a member of the First Church of God, Duffy, Ohio, and of the American Flint Glass Workers Union, No. 510 and had been employed by the Viking Glass Company, of New Martinsville, before she became ill. She is survived by her husband, parents and the following brothers and sisters: Edwin Abrigg, Jr., John, Gerald, Gloria, Jean, Edna, Lila, Rosena, at home and Miss Bernice Abrigg of Wheeling, West Virginia. Funeral services were held on Friday, February 27, from the Methodist Church at Hannibal, at 2:00 P.M. in charge of the Reverend Haden Henthorne of Saltsburg, Pennsylvania, assisted by Robert Lentz of the Church of God, of Duffy, Ohio. Interment was in the Buckhill Bottom cemetery, at Hannibal, in charge of the Wharton and Ellis Funeral Home of New Martinsville, West Virginia.

Abrigg, Edwin

            Military record: Serial number: 2426268. Residence: Woodsfield, Ohio. Enlistment: Regular Army, Woodsfield, Ohio. Enlistment date: April 1, 1918. Birth place: Duffy, Ohio. Age 26 years. Assignment: 15 Company 4 Training Battalion, 158 Depot Brigade to 22 April 1918; Company K 330 Infantry to 30 July 1918; Company G 104 Infantry to Discharge Private St. Mihiel: Meuse- 12 June 1918 to 27 February 1919. Honorable discharge. Volume #1

Source: Monroe County Military records.

Abymer, Isaac         

            Isaac Abymer, aged 83 years, a former resident of Summerfield, Ohio, was instantly killed at Zanesville, Ohio last week when he was struck by an Ohio electric interurban car just west of the State Street bridge in that city.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, June 15, 1916.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Alberta (nee Stephens)

            Alberta Stephens was one of 26 graduating class of 1944 at Lewisville High School. Source: Lewisville, Ohio high school news.

 

Ackerman, Anna and Mr. Charles J. Gramlich    

            Miss Anna Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Ackerman, and Mr. Charles C. Gramlich, were married in Woodsfield, Ohio last Saturday by the Reverend George L. Davis, pastor of the M. E. Church. The bride is a very highly respected young lady of Woodsfield, and the groom is employed in the railroad business at Zanesville, where the happy couple are now located in a home previously furnished for them.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, October 25, 1923

 

Ackerman, Anna L.

            Born: May 10, 1901, in Monroe County, Ohio. Daughter of: Conrad Ackerman and Louise Cecil Ackerman. Died: February 19, 1948, Zanesville, Ohio. Married: Charles J. Gramlich. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Anna C. and George J. Bintz

            Married: February 19, 1882. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Anna Catherine (nee Ludwig)           

            Mrs. Anna Ackerman, 88, of West Newton, Pennsylvania, died Saturday night October 4, 1969, at 11:00 p.m. in Westmoreland Hospital in Greensburg, Pennsylvania. She was born August 3, 1881, at Lewisville, Ohio, a daughter of Louis and Charlotte Weber Ludwig. She lived in Donora, Pennsylvania from 1907 until moving to West Newton 25 years ago. She was a member of Trinity Lutheran Church and the Daughters of America. Her husband Benjamin H. Ackerman died September 24, 1956. Surviving are one son, Arthur B. Ackerman of West Newton, Pennsylvania; two grandchildren, Arthur B. Ackerman, Jr, and Mrs. Ruth Berch, five great-grandchildren, two brothers, George Ludwig of Valencia, Pennsylvania, and William Ludwig of Woodsfield, Ohio, one sister, Mrs. J. D. McAlister of Beallsville, Ohio, a brother David Ludwig and a sister Mrs. Minnie Claus are deceased. Services were held Tuesday afternoon in the Trinity Lutheran Church at Donora, Pennsylvania with pastor Kirk Bish officiating. Burial was in Mon Valley Memorial Park at Donora, Pennsylvania.

 

Ackerman, Arthur B.

            Arthur B. Ackerman of West Newton, RD 1 died yesterday, September 21, 1980, in Westmoreland Hospital, Greensburg. He was 70 years old. Mr. Ackerman was born February 5, 1910, in Donora a son of the late Benjamin and Anna Ludwig Ackerman. He was a retired employee of the former Donora Works of U. S. Steel Corporation. Mr. Ackerman was a member of the Christ Lutheran Church West Newton. Survivors include his wife, Gladys Phythyon Ackerman at home; a daughter, Ruth Berch of West Newton, RD 1; a son Arthur Ackerman, Jr., of McKeesport; and five grandchildren. Friends will be received at the J. William McCauley Funeral Home, West Newton today from 7 to 9 p.m. and tomorrow from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 8:30 p.m.

 

Ackerman, Barbara Jean (nee Miller)      

            Elect Barbara Ackerman, Democrat for Clerk of Courts

            I am Barbara Ackerman, humbly asking for your vote on March 2 for the Clerk of Courts of the Common Pleas. I will bring 12 years experience gained by working in the Clerk of Courts Office for the former Clerk, Dorothy Anderson. I was a hardworking, dedicated and trustworthy County employee who gave 100% to her job. I was proficient in both the legal and title divisions. I have been married to my husband, John, for thirty years and have worked for him in our insurance business for the past 18 years. We live on a farm just north of Woodsfield on SR 800. We have reared two daughters, who are Ohio State University graduates, and who both work and live in Columbus, Ohio. I am serving as the treasurer for the Monroe County Agricultural Society, a Director and Information Coordinator for the Monroe County Farm Bureau. I have worked closely with people in these jobs which gives me the advantage to continue working with the public to serve their needs. I have been entrusted to receipt the Agricultural Societys money, pay bills and work with the State Auditors to balance their accounts. My managerial skills, computer knowledge and accounting experience all help to make me the best candidate. As your Clerk, I would be a courteous and professional servant of the County. Thank you for your consideration.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated Thursday, January 22, 2004.

 

Ackerman, Benjamin H. and Miss Anne C. Ludwig        

            Tuesday morning, December 15, 1903, the marriage of Mr. Benjamin H. Ackerman and Miss Anne C. Ludwig took place at the home of the brides parents near Lewisville, Ohio. Charles W. Neuhart acted as groomsman and Miss Minnie M. Ludwig, sister of the bride, as bridesmaid. They were the recipients of many fine presents and many were the friends and relatives who had gathered to see them start their journey in married life. The Reverend Theodore A. Hafele of Woodsfield performed the marriage ceremony.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, December 17, 1903.

            Benjamin H. Ackerman, age 22 of Monroefield. Parents: Herman and Mary Niesz. Anne C. Ludwig, age 22. Daughter of Louis and Lottie Weber Ludwig.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Benjamin H.

            Benjamin H. Ackerman of West Newton, Pennsylvania, died suddenly at his home at 7:30 p.m. Monday evening September 24, 1956. He was 74 years old.

He was an active member of the Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church and a former Donora Councilman. He had been working in his yard prior to his death and complained of being overheated and shortly after died. He was a son of the late Herman and Mary Niesz Ackerman. He was born November 9, 1881, at Monroefield, Ohio, Monroe County. He went to Donora from Ohio in 1907 and lived there until 1944 when he moved to West Newton, Pennsylvania. He had been retired from 35 years service as a supervisor in the Structural Iron Department at Donora Steel and Wire Works. He is survived by his wife, Anna C. Ludwig Ackerman, one son, Arthur B. Ackerman whose property adjoins his late fathers, one brother, Henry Ackerman, two sisters, Tillie Seebaugh, and Clara Christman, two grandchildren and one great grandchild. Funeral services were held on Thursday afternoon, September 27, 1956, at 2 p.m. in the Trinity Lutheran Church with the Reverend Alex L. Black officiating. Interment was in the Mon Valley Memorial Park at Donora, Pennsylvania.

 

Ackerman, Benjamin P. and Elsie L. Hines

            Benjamin P. Ackerman, age 26, of Monroe County, Ohio. Parents: John and Louisa Christman Ackerman. Married: December 15, 1915, to Elsie L. Hines.

Age 20, of Monroe County. Daughter of Henry and Lizzie Neisz Hines.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Benjamin Philip

            Benjamin Philip Ackerman, 81, died Friday evening May 7, 1970, about 5:30 p.m. from injuries received when a tractor he was operating on his farm near Monroefield, Ohio overturned on him. He was born January 11, 1889, in Monroe County, a son of John and Louise Christman Ackerman. He was married in 1915 to Elsie Hines and had four sons. Surviving are George, Walter, Edward, and Lester Ackerman, nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren and one sister, Mrs. Rosa Schwartz. Funeral services were held Monday afternoon at 2 p.m. in the Gardner Funeral Home at Woodsfield. Burial was in Middle Church cemetery near Lewisville, Ohio. Source: The Wheeling News, May 1970

 

Ackerman, Beula (nee Delong)

            Beula L. Ackerman, 82, of 33749 State Route 78, Lewisville, Ohio, went to be with her Lord on Friday, September 10, 2004, at Marietta Memorial Hospital, Marietta, Ohio. She was born near Calais, Ohio, on July 12, 1922, a daughter of the late Joseph and Josie Carpenter Delong. She attended the former Calais Elementary and High School. She was a full-time homemaker and housewife, and a member of the Calais Church in Calais, Ohio, where she attended her entire life. Her favorite pastime was to embroider gifts for her family. She also enjoyed reading, gardening and canning. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by three sisters, Helen, Dorothy, and Betty; three brothers, Richard, Cletis and Donnie; and one granddaughter, Krista Ackerman. Surviving are her husband of 61 years, Edward H. Ackerman, whom she married on November 4, 1942; four sons, Jimmy (Caroline) Ackerman of Danville, Ohio, Junior (Sheila) Ackerman of Lewisville, Philip (Sally) Ackerman of Beallsville, Ohio, and Ben (Karen) Ackerman of Lewisville; two daughters, Patricia (Eric) Dowler of Parkersburg, West Virginia, and Phyllis (Roger) Claus of Lewisville; two brothers, Guy (Mona) Delong of Salesville, Ohio, and Vance (Rose) Delong of Byesville, Ohio; seven grandchildren, Travis, Jason, Carey, Pam, Russell, Casey and Brittany; two step-grandchildren, Stacey and Missy; three great-grandchildren and seven step-great-grandchildren. Friends will be received at the Watters Funeral Home, 37501 State Route 78 West, Woodsfield, Ohio, from 2 to 9 p.m., Monday, where funeral services will be held at 11 a.m., Tuesday, with Pastor Matt Zurowsky officiating. Burial will follow in the Middle Church Cemetery near Lewisville, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to the Calais Church, 29880 Miltonsburg-Calais Road, Quaker City, Ohio 43773.

Source: The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio, Monday, September 13, 2004.

 

Ackerman, Campie and Charles E. Burgbacher

            Charles E. Burgbacher, age 31, of Monroe County, Ohio. Parents: John and Catherine Dumire Burgbacher. Married on August 23, 1900, to Campie Ackerman. Age 29. Widow. Daughter of: Dawson Whitlatch and Sarah Lowther.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Carrie Eloise

            Born: October 12, 1914, Center Township. Parents: William T. Ackerman and Jessie May Turner. Source: Monroe County birth records.

 

Ackerman, Carey Gail and John Francis Block

            Were united in marriage on August 19 at Saint Benedict Church in Cambridge with Father Robert Borer officiating the double ring ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Connie and Raymond Smithberger, Graysville,and Phil and Sally Ackerman, Beallsville. The bridegroom is the son of Barbara Block, Reynoldsburg and Francis Block, Woodsfield. The bride wore a sleeveless gown with a scooped neckline. The bodice was covered with miniature daisies and satin pearls. The tulle skirt on her gown was complete with seven layers of tulle and satiny polyester. Rows of miniature daisies cascaded from the waistline and trimmed the train of her gown. In memory of her grandmother, Ruth J. Graham, the bride wore her grandmother's engagement ring on her right hand. Alison Killian, cousin of the bride, served as maid of honor, and Francis Block, father of the bridegroom served as best man. Other attendants for the bride were: Pamela Claus, Rochelle Winder, Christy Miller and Ramona Ackerman. Christopher Sturtz, Joseph Block, Casey Ackerman and Tim Kuhn were other attendants for the bridegroom. Stephany Block and Taylor Ackerman were the flower girls and Anthony Block was the ring bearer. Attending the guest book were Krista Ackerman and Brittany Ackerman. Following the ceremony, the reception, coordinated by Cindy Winland, was held in the ballroom of the Lodge at Salt Fork State Park and Resort, Cambridge. The bride is a 1995 graduate of Monroe Central High School and a 1999 graduate of Ohio University. She is currently employed as an Ohio AppalCORPS tutor and as a substitute teacher for the Switzerland of Ohio Local School District. She is also pursuing a second degree in Middle Childhood Education from Ohio University. The bridegroom is a 1990 graduate of Westerville North High School. He is a veteran of Desert Storm, serving in the United States Army for eight years. Currently, he is employed by Shadow Lake Campground and Resort. Following their honeymoon at Walt Disney World's Old Key West Resort in Orlando, Florida, the couple now resides with their two children in Miltonsburg. Source: Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio. Published: January 11, 2001.

 

Ackerman, Celestia Elizabeth

            Born: January 1, 1912, Woodsfield, Ohio. Parents: William Ackerman and Mary M. Christman. Source: Monroe County birth records.

1930 Ohio Census:

            Celestia was 18 yrs. old, born about 1912 in Ohio. Both her parents were born in Ohio. She was single. She was attending school and could read, write,

and speak English. She did not have an occupation. She was living with her

parents, William and Mary M., and brother, Raymond W., on Roy Street,

Woodsfield, Center Township, Monroe County, Ohio. Source: Year: 1930 Census Place: Woodsfield, Monroe County, Ohio. Roll: T626_1851. Page: 16B. Enumeration District: 4. Image: 0078. cp. 33.

 

Ackerman, Celestia E. Rubel        

            Born: January 1, 1912. Death: March 1, 1994. Services at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, Ohio on March 5, 1994, at 11 a.m. Officiating: Reverend Ed Thurmond. Interment: Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

Source: Memory card. 

 

Ackerman, Charles

            Charles Ackerman, aged 75, passed away at his home on West Marietta Street, Saturday evening at six oclock. He had been in failing health for several weeks but only seriously ill since last Tuesday. He was united in marriage (February 5, 1896) with Margaret Knoch, who passed away in October 1921. He later married Lida Spence, who survives. Also surviving besides his wife, are one daughter, Mrs. Louis R. Schumacher, of Woodsfield Rt. 1; one stepdaughter, Mrs. Clarence Lafferre, of Robinson, Illinois; one sister, Mrs. Charles Brubach, and one brother, Henry Ackerman, both of Woodsfield; also several grandchildren. The body was brought to the Galbraith Funeral Home where funeral services will be held Tuesday afternoon at two oclock, with the Reverend Walter R. Trogler, of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, officiating. Burial will be in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, June 11, 1945.

 

Ackerman, Clara Gertrude and J. W. Christman

            J. W. Christman; age 30 years on the 7th day of September 1902. Birthplace: Calais, Monroe County, Ohio. Occupation: farmer. Father: John Christman. Mother: Eva Pfalzgraf. License was issued on February 25, 1903, and married March 4, 1903, to Clara Ackerman. Age 27. Birthplace, Lewisville, Monroe County. Occupation: housekeeper. Father: Herman Ackerman. Mother: Mary Neisz. Married by Otto Albrecht, Evangelist pastor.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

Ackerman, Clarence H.

            Barnesville, Ohio-Clarence H. Ackerman, 89 of 55510 Washington St., Somerton, died Thursday (November 7, 1991) at Barnesville Hospital. He was born May 10, 1902, in Somerton son of the late Henry and Louise Christman Ackerman. He retired from Timken Roller Bearing, Canton, Ohio, and was a member of Somerton United Methodist Church. He was preceded in death by three brothers, George, Samuel and Roy Ackerman; and one sister Freda Froehlich. Mr. Ackerman leaves his wife, Mildred Dewar Ackerman; two sons, Clarence J. Ackerman of Somerton and Paul W. Ackerman of Jerusalem; three sisters, Mary Fisher of Barnesville; Stella Nepturne of the state of Kansas and Trella Froehlich of Somerton; five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

            Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday at Campbell-Plumly-Milburn Funeral Home, where services will be at 12:30 p.m. Sunday with the Reverend Susan Yackey officiating. Burial will be in the Somerton Cemetery.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, November 1991.

 

Ackerman, Conrad and Louisa C. Cecil

            Married: March 31, 1878. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Conrad

            Died: May 7, 1925, Woodsfield. Born: October 22, 1858. Occupation: farmer. Source: Monroe County death records. Volume number: 4749.

Certificate number: 30631.

 

Ackerman, Dorthea Catherine

            Born: March 22, 1911, Center Township. Parents: Henry Ackerman and Bertie B. Longdon. Source: Monroe County birth records.

 

Ackerman, Dorothy and Mr. Francis Burkhart                 

            Miss Dorothy Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman, of Woodsfield Route 3, and Mr. Francis Burkhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. N. Burkhart, also of Woodsfield Route 3 were united in marriage at 7:00 oclock on Monday morning, January 9, 1933, at St. Sylvesters Catholic Church, Woodsfield. The pastor, Reverend J. G. Mehler, officiated at the exchange of the marriage vows. The attendants were Mrs. Edith Cannon, of Columbus, Ohio and John Burkhart, of Woodsfield, sister and brother of the groom. A few near relatives and friends also witnessed the ceremony. Following the wedding a breakfast was served at the Columbia Hotel to the following: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Burkhart, Mrs. Edith Cannon, John Burkhart, Reverend J. G. Mehler and Charles Brubach.

The bride and groom are both members of fine families and have the best wishes of their many friends.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, January 12, 1933.

 

Ackerman, Douglas A, Master Sergeant

            Master Sergeant Douglas A. Ackerman was honored recently in Washington D.C., as one of the United States Air Force's 12 outstanding airmen of the year of 2003. He was selected from approximately 300,000 airmen. He is the son of Fred and Martha Ackerman of Woodsfield.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, Published: October 2003.

 

Ackerman, Edna Pearl

            Died: July 21, 1929, Adams Township. Age 39 years. Source: Monroe County death records. Volume number: 6050. Certificate number: 48546.

 

Ackerman, Edward Henry

            Edward was one of 18 in his graduating class of 1940 at Lewisville High school. Source: Lewisville, Ohio high school news.

 

Ackerman, Elizabeth and Sylvester Nalley

            Married: September 17, 1878. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Elizabeth Dorothea Claus      

            Elizabeth Claus, nee Ackerman, was born February 7, 1819, in Hannasfield, Spanixburg, Hastelcastel, Germany. (daughter of Adam Ackerman and Katharina Paul) In 1843 she united in marriage to Henry Claus, Sr. and they shared each other's joys and sorrows for fifty-eight years. In the year 1847 they came to America and made their home near Monroefield, Ohio and became members of the Miltonsburg Evangelical Church. They had two sons born in Germany - Justus and (Casper, who died while crossing the ocean). The other children (born here) were Elizabeth, Henry, Adolph and Fredrick. She took sick about the 24th day of June, and died on Sunday morning, July 7, 1901. She leaves her husband, five children, 34 grandchildren, and eleven great-grandchildren. She had reached the age of 82 years, five months. Sister of Conrad Ackerman.

 

Ackerman, Eloise and Mr. William E. Smith       

            Using the single ring ceremony, William E. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Smith, of Eastern Avenue, and Miss Eloise Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Ackerman, of Woodsfield, were united in marriage, Saturday, May 6th, at 11:00 p.m., at the Evangelical parsonage. The Reverend R. W. Jungfer, Jr., performed the nuptial ceremony. Attendants were William F. Smith, of Marietta, Ohio and Mrs. R. W. Jungfer, Jr. Mr. Smith is a graduate of Woodsfield High School, class of 30 and is the proprietor of a cleaning and pressing business on South Main Street. The bride is a graduate of Woodsfield High School, class of 34 and is an attractive and talented young lady. They will make their home on Church Street. Many friends extend congratulations.

 Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, May 11, 1939.

Ackerman, Fred, Jr. and Kimberly Paige Burns

            Haleigh and Ryan Ackerman and Katherine Fickell wish to announce the marriage of their parents , Fred Ackerman, Jr. and Kimberly Paige Burns. The couple was married in a double ring ceremony at their home in Woodsfield, with family and friends attending. Judge James Peters performed the ceremony. Fred, the son of Fred Sr., and Martha Ackerman, Woodsfield, is plant manager at Alumitech of West Virginia. Kim, the daughter of Monna Burns and Russell burns, both of Columbus, is an RN, working in the special care nursery at Genesis Health Center, Zanesville. A reception immediately followed the ceremony.

Source: Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio. Published--April 8, 2002.

 

Ackerman, Freda Lucinda Froehlich        

            Freda L. Froehlich, 84, 36328 Flatrock Road, Barnesville, died December 8, 1988, at her residence. She was born August 24, 1904, in Belmont County, the daughter of the late Henry and Louise Christman Ackerman. She was a member of the Somerton United Methodist Church. She was preceded in death by three brothers: Sam, George, and Roy Ackerman, and one great-grandchild.

Surviving are her husband, Fred of Barnesville; two daughters, Mrs. Willis (Patricia) Yarnall of Somerton; three sisters, Mrs. Mary Fisher, Mrs. Trella Froehlich of Barnesville, and Mrs. Stella Neptune of Shawnee Mission, Kansas; five grandchildren; four great-grandchildren. Services were held December 10 at the Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home in Barnesville with the Reverend James Schoonover officiating. Burial was in Crestview Cemetery, Barnesville, Ohio.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, December 1988.

 

Ackerman, George Benjamin

George B. Ackerman

            George was one of 16 in his graduating class of 1936 at Lewisville High School. Source: Lewisville, Ohio high school news.

George B. Ackerman

            Corporal George B., son of Ben Ackerman of Lewisville, Route 1, was

inducted in the Army on February 15, 1943. He was inducted at Parkersburg, West Virginia, and was first sent to California. Corporal Ackerman is now stationed at Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Aberdeen, Maryland. He is graduate of the 1936 class of Lewisville high school.

Source: The Zanesville Signal, Zanesville, Ohio, Wednesday, July 28, 1943.

 

Ackerman, George B.

            George B. Ackerman, son of Benjamin Ackerman was inducted into the Army February 15, 1943. He is a graduate of Lewisville High school in 1936 and attended Marietta Business College. Source: Monroe County Beacon, 1943.

 

Ackerman, George Gilbert 

            Somerton, Ohio - George Gilbert Ackerman, 71, of Somerton was dead on arrival at Barnesville General Hospital at 2 a.m. Tuesday of an apparent heart attack. Born near Somerton, February, 17, 1900, he was a son of Henry and Louise Christman Ackerman. He was retired as superintendent of Belmont County Highway Department this year and was a member of Somerton United Methodist Church. Surviving are his widow, Ethel; two sons, Stanley of Cleveland Heights and Roger, serving with the Air Force in California; a daughter, Mrs. John (Lois Jean) Baker of Lewisville; 10 grandchildren; two brothers, Sam and Clarence both of Somerton; four sisters, Mrs. Freda Froelich and Mrs. Trella Froelich, both of Barnesville Route 1, Mrs. Mary Fisher of Barnesville and Mrs. Stella Nepturne of Kansas City, Kansas. Friends may call at Steele Funeral Home in Somerton this afternoon and evening. Services will be held at 2 p.m. Thursday at Somerton United Methodist Church with the Reverend Gail Smith officiating.

Burial will be in Somerton Cemetery.

Source: Newspaper article dated September 14, 1971

George Gilbert Ackerman:

            Volume: 20587. Certificate: 063725. Autopsy: No. Autopsy Gender: Male

Date of Death: September 14, 1971. Age: 71 Years. Marital Status: Married. Residence: Belmont County. Certifier: Physician. Place of Death: Belmont County, Race: White. Source: Ohio Deaths, 1958-2000.

 

Ackerman, Gladys Amelia (nee Phythyon)                      

            Gladys Amelia (Phythyon) Ackerman, 82, West Newton, R.D. 1 died on Wednesday, May 30, 1990, in Monsour Medical Hospital, Jeannette. She was born on August 22, 1907, in Sewickley Township, a daughter of the late Mary Edna Brown Phythyon Lacey and Edward Phythyon. Prior to retirement, she was an elementary school teacher in the Yough School District. She was also a member of Faith Lutheran Church in White Oak. Mrs. Ackerman was preceded in death by her husband, Arthur B. Ackerman and an infant son. She is survived by a daughter, Ruth Berch of West Newton R.D. 1; a son Reverend Arthur B. Ackerman, Jr. of White Oak; a sister Neva Jerome of Dover, Ohio; and five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Friends will be received on Thursday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the J. William McCauley Funeral Home Inc., West Newton.

 

Ackerman, Harold Guy

            Born: October 15, 1919, Center Township. Parents: William Ackerman and Jessie M. Turner. Source: Monroe County birth records.

 

Ackerman, Helen Jane and Mr. Ward Strickling 

            Mrs. W. T. Ackerman, of Woodsfield, Route four, announces the marriage of her daughter, Miss Helen Jane Ackerman, to Ward Strickling, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Strickling, of Woodsfield, Route three. The Reverend H. J. Kopke, pastor of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, officiated at the ceremony on Friday, August 21, 1953, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Smith, on East Church Street. Reverend Kopke read the vows at eight-thirty oclock in the evening in the presence of members of the immediate families. Attendants were the brides brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. William E. Smith.  The bride wore a blue nylon dress with white accessories and a corsage of yellow Rosebuds. Mrs. Smith wore a blue and white ensemble with white accessories and a corsage of pink Rosebuds. Immediately following the ceremony a reception was held. The brides table was centered with a three-tiered wedding cake and vases of red Roses. The newlyweds left later in the evening for a wedding trip through the Eastern states. The new Mrs. Strickling is a graduate of Woodsfield high school, class of 1952. She is now employed at the Cline Truck & Equipment company. Mr. Strickling is a 1949 graduate of Lewisville high school, and is a member of the National Guard. He is employed with he Baker Coal company near Stafford, Ohio. Mr. and Mrs. Strickling are residing in the Adams apartment, 434 Eastern Avenue, Woodsfield.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, August 1953.

 

Ackerman, Helen and Mr. Edward F. Pickens    

            Miss Helen Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman, north of Woodsfield, and Edward F. Pickens, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pickens, of Lewisville, Ohio were united in marriage at 7:15 oclock, Saturday evening, February 25th. Minister J. V. A. Traylor, pastor of the Woodsfield Church of Christ, officiated at the exchange of marriage vows at his home on Eastern Avenue. The attendants were Mr. and Mrs. Leighton Weber, sister and brother-in-law of the bride. The bride was attired in teal blue with accessories to match.

Both Mr. and Mrs. Pickens have many friends who join in extending congratulations and best wishes.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, March 2, 1939

            Edward F. Pickens was one of 23 in his graduating class of 1935 at Lewisville High School. Source: Lewisville, Ohio High School news.

 

Ackerman, Henri C. and Louise Christman

Ackerman, Henri C.

            Henri C. Ackerman, 91, of Somerton died Monday morning, October 17, 1960, at 10:15 o'clock, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Clem Froehlich, on Barnesville, Route one. He was born November 27, 1868, in Benwood, West Virginia, a son of Herman and Mary Niesz Ackerman, and had resided there for some time. He was a member of the Methodist Church. Surviving are three sons, Sam Ackerman of Malaga; George Ackerman and Clarence Ackerman of Somerton; four daughters, Mrs. Alfreda Froehlich, Mrs. Mary Fisher and Mrs. Trella Froehlich, all of Barnesville Route and Mrs. Stella Nepture, of Kansas City, Kansas; two sisters, Mrs. Clara Christman, of Calais and Mrs. Tillie Sebach, of Alliance, Ohio. One son, Roy is deceased. His wife Louise died in 1919. Funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon at two o'clock in the Methodist Church at Somerton with the Reverend William Irvin officiating. Interment was in the Somerton Cemetery.  Source: The Monroe County Beacon, October 1960.

 

Ackerman, Henry

            A serious accident, which proved to be fatal to one of the party, occurred on the National paved highway near the John Israel homestead last Sunday evening. Mr. Henry Ackerman, his wife and several children were driving an automobile headed west when in some unexplainable manner the machine became uncontrollable and ran off the paving on to the berm. When the driver tried to right the machine, the front wheels struck a high place in the curbing, upsetting the auto and its occupants were all thrown into a frightened heap. Mrs. Ackerman was very seriously injured by having several bones broken. She was taken to her home in an ambulance and death occurred Tuesday night, never having regained consciousness. Mr. Ackerman and the remaining members of his family were painfully though not seriously hurt. The Ackermans are farmer folks living between Somerton, Ohio and Malaga, Ohio and a prominent and well-to-do people. Mrs. Ackerman was probably 50 years of age.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, June 5, 1919.

 

Ackerman, Henry F. and Birtie B. Longdon

            Henry F. Ackerman, age 25, of Monroe County, Ohio. Parents: Paulus and Katharine Schwensberg Ackerman. Married December 25, 1905, to Birtie B. Longdon, age 21, of Monroe County. Daughter of Abe and Julia Lowe Longdon.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Henry F.

            Born: September 12, 1880. Died: July 15, 1969. Residence: Woodsfield, Ohio. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Herman

            Died: February 27, 1919. Born: May 15, 1837 in Germany. Father: Conrad Ackerman. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Herman

            Herman Ackerman, the subject of this sketch, was born on the 15th day of February, 1837, in Landefeld, near Spangenburg Gur-Hessan, Germany. His parents being interested more in his spiritual than in his material welfare had him confirmed in the Christian faith while yet in the Fatherland on May 21st, 1851.  In the year 1857, on the 11th day of April, he left the Fatherland and sailed to America and landed in Wheeling, West Virginia, on July 22nd of the same year. On March 16, 1862, he was united in marriage to Mary Niesz, and to this union seven children were born, three sons and four daughters. Anna, the eldest of the children, preceded him to the better land on March 1, 1896. He leaves to mourn, his devoted wife and the following children, John Ackerman, near home; Henry Ackerman, of Somerton; Benjamin Ackerman, of Donora, Pennsylvania; Mrs. Jacob Christman, near home; Mrs. John Christman, of Calais, Ohio; and Mrs. John Seebach, of Alliance. Also twenty-nine grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. The first ten years of their married life was spent in Benwood and Wheeling, West Virginia. In March 1872, they moved from Wheeling to Ohio near Monroefield on the farm known as the Jacob Bertram farm; here they lived dividing their joys and sorrows till in the fall of 1889, when they moved to the farm on which he died, which was on the 27th day of February 1919, being at the time 82 years and 12 days old.  In November last he took sick with that dreaded disease pneumonia from which he never recovered. During his illness he was tenderly cared for by his loving wife and children and grandchildren, but more especially by two grandchildren, Clara Bintz and Viola Bintz, who were constantly at his bedside doing all that loving hands could do to restore him to health, but to no avail. He was laid away to await the resurrection morn on Sunday, March 2nd, in the St. Johns Middle Church cemetery, followed by a large concourse of friends and relatives, amid beautiful floral offerings. The funeral was conducted by his former pastor, the Reverend Paul Saleske, of Chicago, Illinois.

Tis hard to break the tender cord

When Love has bound the heart,

Tis hard so hard to speak the words

Must we forever part.

 

Dearest loved one we have laid thee,

In the peaceful graves embrace.

But thy memory will be cherished

Till we see thy heavenly face.

 

We miss thee from our home, dear,

We miss thee from thy place,

A shadow oer our life is cast.

We miss the sunshine of thy face,

 

We miss thy kind and willing hand,

Thy fond and Earnest care,

Our home is dark without thee

We miss thee everywhere.

 

Oh, then let us all be ready,

When the call for us shall come,

To meet you dear father

                                                            In that happy, happy, land.               

A FRIEND.

Source: Newspaper clipping, February 1919.

            Jacob Ackerman, of near Woodsfield, died Saturday, October 10, 1898. His burial was made in the Woodsfield cemetery. His wife and several children survive. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, October 13, 1898.

Ackerman, John Adam

            Woodsfield-Funeral services for John Ackerman will be held at the home of his son, Ben Ackerman, Lewisville Route one, Saturday afternoon at 1:30 with the Reverend Floyd Workman of Lewisville Methodist church officiating, to be followed by final rites at Saint John's Evangelical and Reformed church near Lewisville. Interment will be made in the church cemetery. He passed away in Bucyrus Wednesday following an operation for appendicitis two weeks ago.

             In addition to his son, he is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Chester Schwartz of Bucyrus. Source: The Zanesville Signal, Friday, September 2, 1949, page 8.

 

Ackerman, John A.

            John A. Ackerman, of Lewisville, Route 1, died about 12:15 o'clock

Wednesday afternoon, August 31, 1949, on his 84th birthday. His death occurred at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Chester Schwartz, of near Bucyrus, Ohio, where he had been visiting for about two weeks. He was born August 31, 1865, the son of Herman and Mary Ackerman, at Wheeling, W. Va.  At the age of eight years he moved with his parents to Monroe County. He was a member of the Evangelical Church of near Lewisville. He was united in marriage with Louise Christman on January 5, 1888. To this union were born two children, Benjamin Ackerman, of Lewisville, Route 1 and Mrs. Chester Schwartz of Bucyrus, Ohio.

His first wife died September 18, 1890. He was then united in marriage with Magdalena Christman on November 1, 1891. To this union were born two children who died in infancy. He was preceded in death by his second wife on August 23, 1943; one sister, Anna Bintz, and one stepson. He is survived in addition to his two children, by two brothers, Henry Ackerman, of Somerton, Ohio and Ben Ackerman of West Newton, Pa.; three sisters, Mrs. Mary Christman of Lewisville Route 1; Mrs. Matilda Seebaugh of Alliance, Ohio and Mrs. Clara Christman of Quaker City, Ohio; nine grand children, ten great grand children and seven step grandchildren. He was a retired farmer and has made his home for the past several years with his son. His death was a severe shock to his relatives and many friends.

When I shall come to the end of my way

When I shall rest at the close of life's day

When welcome home, I shall hear Jesus say

Oh, that will be sunrise for me.

 

When in His beauty I see the great king,

Join with the ransomed His praises to sin

When I shall join them my tributes to bring

Oh, that will be sunrise for me.

 

When life is over and daylight is past

In Heaven's harbor my anchor is cast

When I see Jesus my Savior at last

Oh that will be sunrise for me.

 

Sunrise tomorrow sunrise tomorrow

Sunrise in glory is waiting for me

Sunrise tomorrow sunrise tomorrow

Sunrise with Jesus for eternity.

 

Ackerman, Juanita K. (nee Buchanan)    

            Mrs. Juanita K. Ackerman, 27, of 211 Prior Road, Pataskala, Ohio died Wednesday morning, December 12, 1973, in Mount Carmel East Hospital, Columbus, following an illness. She was born in Parkersburg, West Virginia, September 7, 1946, the daughter of John and Hazel Holiday Buchanan. Mrs. Ackerman was a member of the First Baptist Church, at Etna, Ohio. Surviving are her husband, Jimmy Ackerman; one son, Jimmy Travis Ackerman of the home; her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Buchanan of Newark, and two brothers, Edsel Buchanan of Newark, and Olan Archer of Reader, West Virginia. Funeral services were held Saturday morning at ten o'clock in the First Baptist Church at Etna, with the Reverend Danny Smith officiating. Graveside services and burial were at the Middle Church Cemetery, near Lewisville, Saturday afternoon at two o'clock with the Brucker and Kishler Funeral Home of Newark in charge.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, December 20, 1973.

            Gender: Female. Date of Death: December 12, 1973. Volume: 21524.

Ackerman, Krista Lynn

             Lewisville, Ohio-Krista Lynn Ackerman, 16, of 32778 Skin Creek Road, Lewisville, Ohio, died Friday (February 14, 2003) at her home. She was born April 3, 1986, in Cambridge to Junior and Sheila McVicker Ackerman. She was a junior at Monroe Central High School near Woodsfield, where she was a member of the Teen Institute, yearbook staff, ski club and was also an honor student. Krista died immediately from self-inflicted gunshot wounds. She attended the Calais Church at Calais and had accepted the Lord at an early age. In addition to her parents, she is survived by three sisters, Brittany Ackerman at home, Stacey Buzzard of Zanesville and Melissa Cecil of Woodsfield; paternal grandparents, Edward and Beula Ackerman of Lewisville; maternal grandparents, Billy McVicker of Quaker City and Clarice McVicker of Cambridge; one niece, Courtne Buzzard of Zanesville; three nephews, Josiah Buzzard and Micah Buzzard, both of Zanesville, and Cody Cecil of Woodsfield; and several aunts, uncles and cousins. Services are at 2 p.m. Monday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Pastor James Brown officiating. Burial is in Middle Church Cemetery near Lewisville. Friends will be received from 2 to 9 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home.

Source: The Marietta Times, Saturday, February 15, 2003.

 

Ackerman, Lawrence

             Lawrence Ackerman, age 12, was accidentally struck by an automobile driven by Arnold Schwall of Woodsfield last Tuesday afternoon. The accident occurred one mile east of Lewisville on the Lewisville-Woodsfield Road. Lawrence suffered a fractured skull and crushed chest when he struck the pavement. Lawrence was coming toward Woodsfield with his little wagon. When he came to the driveway of a filling station, Mr. Schwall approached him from the rear and blew his horn. Instead of turning off the main highway into the driveway to let Mr. Schwall pass, Lawrence turned directly across the pavement in front of the car. It is believed that he thought Mr. Schwall wanted to drive into the driveway of the filling station and turned across the pavement to get out of the way. Lawrence was removed to a Barnesville hospital where he died early Thursday morning. Since the death of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Ackerman, he had made his home with Mr. and Mrs. Fred Weber, one mile east of Lewisville. Mabel Ackerman of Woodsfield is a sister of Lawrence.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, August 18, 1938.

 

Ackerman, Lester

            Lester was one of 26 graduating class of 1944 at Lewisville High School.

Source: Lewisville, Ohio high school news.

 

Ackerman, Lois and John Baker

            John and Lois (nee Ackerman) Baker celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary on June 20, 2004. The couple was married in Somerton United Methodist Church June 20, 1954, with the Reverend Joseph Craig officiating.

John is the son of the late Charles and Mary M. Baker of Lewisville. Lois is the daughter of the late George and Ethel Ackerman of Somerton. The couple has been greatly blessed with three children, Steve (Chriss) Baker of Woodsfield; Rhonda (Kevin) Marshall of Lewisville and Greg (Chris) Baker of Lewisville. The family circle includes five wonderful grandchildren, Chad and Cody Baker; Nikki Baker and Scott and Casey Marshall. The couple celebrated their special day with a surprise dinner given by the family at River City Restaurant in Parkersburg, West Virginia.  Source: The Monroe County Beacon, July 8, 2004.

 

Ackerman, Lorena (nee Steele)   

            Lorena Ackerman, 92, resident of the Wesley Glen Nursing Home for the last 4 years, passed away on Saturday, November 11, 2000, at the nursing home. She was born on December 16, 1907, in Senecaville, daughter of the late Charles and Suzanna (Rogers) Steele. In addition to her parents, she is preceded in death by her husband Frank Ackerman and also by 4 sisters.  She is survived by a son, David Ackerman of Maineville; daughter, Carol Parker of Columbus; 5 grandchildren; 3 great-grandchildren. No calling hours will be observed. Graveside service will be held on Tuesday, November 14, 2000, at 11 a.m. at the Senecaville Cemetery, Senecaville, Ohio. A memorial service will be held in Columbus, Ohio at a later date. Meek-Black Funeral Home, Senecaville, is handling arrangements.

Source: The Columbus Dispatch, Columbus, Ohio, November 14, 2000.

 

Ackerman, Louisa (nee Pfalzgraf)

            Louisa Christman Ackerman was born March 15, 1866. Daughter of Philip H. Christman and Rosina Pfalzgraf. Occupation: housewife. Spouse of John Adam Ackerman. Louisa died September 10, 1890, age 24 years. and 6 months, Seneca township, Monroe County, Ohio. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Louisa L.

            Mrs. Louisa L. Ackerman, 85, of the Adamsville Road, Zanesville, Ohio died at 12:50 oclock Monday morning at Bethesda hospital, Zanesville, of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was admitted to the hospital Sunday afternoon. Her husband, Conrad, died twenty-one years ago. She is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Charles L. Gramlich, of Adamsville Road; a son, Charles Ackerman, of Miami, Florida; two nephews, Ernest Cecil, of Caldwell, and Robert Cecil, of Woodsfield; eighteen grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. The body was brought to the Bauer and Turner funeral home at Woodsfield, Wednesday, where services will be conducted Thursday afternoon at one oclock, with the Reverend Walter Trogler officiating. Burial will be in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio. Mrs. Ackerman was a member of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church in Woodsfield.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, January 9, 1947.

 

Ackerman, Louise

            Died: June 1919. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Lidia and Mr. Charles T. Brubach     

            Miss Lidia Ackerman, age 31. Parents: Paulus and Elizabeth Schausbach Ackerman. Married: In Monroe County, Ohio on November 10, 1903 to Mr. Charles T. Brubach, age 31. Parents: Jakob and Mary Nauer Brubach.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Lyda (nee Spence)     

            Mrs. Lyda Ackerman, daughter of James and Elizabeth Spence, was born November 5, 1874, Monroe County, Ohio, and died Saturday night, February 1st 1947, in the Schmidt Clinic, in Robinson, Illinois, at the age of 72 years, two months and twenty-six days. Mrs. Ackerman had been a resident of Woodsfield until January 19 when she left to make her home with her daughter, Mrs. Clarence Lafferre in Robinson. She took seriously ill on the 22nd. On November 13, 1923, she was united in marriage with Charles Ackerman who preceded her in death on June 10, 1945. Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. Lafferre, and one stepdaughter, Mrs. Louis R. Schumacher, of Woodsfield; seven grandchildren; one sister, Mrs. Jennie Denbow, of Lewisville; two brothers, James Spence, of Lewisville, Ohio, and Charles Spence, of Ashland, Ohio; and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services were held at the Galbraith funeral home on Wednesday afternoon, at two oclock, with the Reverend Walter Trogler, of Saint Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, officiating. Burial was made beside her husband in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Monday, February 10, 1947.

 

Ackerman, Magdalena (Lena) (nee Christman) 

             Woodsfield - Mrs. Lena Christman Ackerman, 85, died Monday at her home on Lewisville Route one, after an illness of several years. Funeral services will be held Friday morning at 10 o'clock at the home by Reverend Walter Togler, pastor of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, Woodsfield. Burial will be at the cemetery of St. John's Church, Summit township. Mrs. Ackerman was born in Monroefield, the daughter of Philip and Rosina Pfalzgraf Christman.

Surviving are her husband, John A. Ackerman, and two step children, Ben Ackerman, Lewisville Route one, and Mrs. Chester Schwartz of Bucyrus and seven grandchildren. Also surviving are one brother, George L. Christman of Lewisville Route one, two sisters, Mrs. Barbara Morris of Salesville, and Mrs. Mary Miller of Quaker City. She was one of a family of 12 children. Two brothers and six sisters preceded her in death.

Source: The Zanesville Signal, Zanesville, Ohio, Wednesday, August 25, 1943.

 

Ackerman, Margaret

            Margaret Ackerman, estimable wife of Charles Ackerman, died at her home on West Marietta Street, Woodsfield, at 6:00 oclock Saturday evening, October 8, 1921, aged 54 years. She was born January 17, 1867. Mrs. Ackerman was of a cheerful nature and honorable disposition to the extent that she had many friends. She leaves a devoted husband, one daughter, Estella Ackerman, and many other relatives and friends. The funeral services, conducted by the Reverend Father Seeber, took place at the Catholic church last Tuesday morning. Interment in the Catholic cemetery.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, October 13, 1921.

 

Ackerman, Martha C.

            Martha C. was 85 yrs. old, born about 1845 in Germany. Both her parents were born in Germany, speaking German. She was widowed. She became a

naturalized citizen in 1856. She could not read or write. She could speak English. She lived with her son and his family, William and Mary M. and grandchildren, Elizabeth and Raymond, on Lewisville Road, in Woodsfield, Center Township, Monroe County, Ohio. Source: 1920 Census, Woodsfield, Center Township, Monroe County, Ohio, ED 47, Sheet 8A; image 159.

 

Ackerman, Martha Elizabeth

            Died July 18, 1890, age 1 month and 24 days in Center township.

Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Martha Katherine

            Died: November 5, 1920, Woodsfield. Born: February 13, 1834, Germany.  Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Ackerman, Mary and Jacob Christman

            Married: March 13, 1892. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, Mary Christman           

            Mrs. Mary Christman, age 80, of Lewisville, Ohio, Route one, died at 11 oclock Friday morning, February 8, 1952, at her home following a brief illness.

She was born in Wheeling, West Virginia, a daughter of Herman and Mary Ackerman. She spent most of her life in Monroe County, Ohio. Her husband, Jacob Christman, died 20 years ago. Surviving are two brothers, Henry Ackerman, and Benjamin Ackerman; two sisters, Mrs. Matilda Seebach, and Mrs. Clara Christman. Funeral services will be held this Monday afternoon at one oclock at the Calais cemetery, Calais, Ohio with the Brubach funeral home of Summerfield, Ohio in charge. Source: Newspaper clipping, February 1952.

 

Ackerman, Mary (nee Niesz)         

            Mrs. Herman Ackerman, nee Mary Niesz, was born in Birmingham, now Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on June 11, 1843. At the age of three years, her parents moved to Monroe County, Ohio and located in Malaga Township where she resided until her death. In 1862 she was married to Herman Ackerman. This union was blessed with seven children; Anna Bintz, John Ackerman and Henry Ackerman of Somerton; Mary Christman of Lewisville; Matilda Seebach of Limaville; Clara Christman of Calais, and Benjamin Ackerman of Donora, Pennsylvania. Anna preceded her on March 1, 1896. Her husband preceded her on February 27, 1919. Mrs. Ackerman died on June 22, 1939, about 8:30 a.m. at the home of Mrs. Jacob Christman at the age of 96 years and 11 days. She leaves to mourn her, besides the children, the following: twenty-nine grandchildren, sixty-seven great-grandchildren one great-great-grandchild and a host of other relatives and friends. Funeral services were held on Sunday morning, June 25th, at Saint Johns Middle Church in charge of Reverend W. R. Walch. Burial was made in the Church Cemetery.

 

Ackerman, Mary E. and Forest H. Hall

            Married September 6, 1884. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

Ackerman, Mildred Grace (nee Dewar)               

            Volume: 31695. Certificate: 076920. Autopsy: No. Gender: Female.

Date of Death: October 8, 1998. Social Security Number: 284681175. Birth Date:10 May 1903. Father's Surname: Dewar. Time of Death: 4:30 PM. Age: 95.

Hispanic Origin: Non Hispanic. Years of Schooling: 9. Certifier: Physician.

Referred to Coroner: No. Method of Disposition: Burial. Place of Death: Hospital/Inpatient. Race: White. Source: Ohio Deaths, 1958-2000.

 

Ackerman, Myron H. and Gladys Louise Stephens        

            Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Stephens, of Atlas Star Route, Barnesville are announcing the marriage of their daughter, Gladys Louise to Myron H. Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Ackerman of near Malaga. The double ring ceremony was solemnized on May 30, 1947, at 2:30 p.m. by Reverend C. G. Bloor at Belmont. The bride wore a floor length gown of White net over taffeta, fashioned with a sweetheart neckline edged in a small net ruffle, tiny puffed sleeves and tight bodice with full skirt. Her shoulder length veil fell from a White cap. She wore elbow length White gloves and carried a White Bible showered with pink Roses and streamers knotted with Rose petals. She wore a strand of pearls, gift of the groom. Miss Vivian Haga of Somerton was maid of honor and wore a floor length gown of pink taffeta fashioned with sweetheart neckline and cap sleeves and small bustle. She carried a colonial bouquet of Roses and carnations, tied with a satin ribbon. The gift of the bride was a round gold compact. Mr. Emery Stewart, Jr., of Barnesville serviced the groom as best man. Shortly after the ceremony, a reception was held at the bride's home. Both the bride and groom are graduates of Somerset Twp. High School, class of 1945. At present the bride is employed in the First Aid Room of the Continental Can Company of Cambridge. The groom served 14 months with the U. S. Army, 10 months being overseas duty. After a trip through the western states the couple will reside at 116 N. 6th Street, Cambridge, Ohio.

Source: The Monroe County Republican, June 12, 1947.

Ackerman, Pauline and Ray Clarence Taylor                 

            Miss Pauline Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman, of Woodsfield, became the bride of Private Ray Clarence Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Taylor, also of Woodsfield, on Wednesday evening, December 29th. Reverend Walter Trogler read the single ring ceremony in the parsonage of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church of South Main Street. The couple was unattended. Mrs. Taylor returned to Columbus where she is employed. Private Taylor, who had been enrolled in the University of Oregon at Corvallis, Oregon, in the A. S. T. program, has been transferred to Camp Carson, Colorado, where he is now stationed. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, January 10, 1943.

 

Ackerman, Paulus

            Paulus Ackerman, aged 66 years, 3 months, and 21 days, died at his home two miles west of Woodsfield, Center township, on Monday, January 10, 1910. He was born in Hessen, Germany, September 19, 1833. He arrived in Wheeling, West Virginia in 1856. He was married in Wheeling to Martha C. Ackerman and lived there one year, then moved to Monroe County, Ohio. Seven sons and three daughters survive: Conrad, Charles, Jacob, and Henry F. Ackerman, Mrs. Sylvester Nalley, Mrs. Forrest H. Hall and Mrs. Louisa Brubach of near Woodsfield, William and Jacob Ackerman of the home. Two sons died previously. The funeral was held at Saint Pauls Evangelical Church, Woodsfield on Wednesday, January 14. His wife survives.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, January 20, 1910.

 

Ackerman, Phil

            Phil Ackerman, was named superintendant of the Switzerland of Ohio Local School District at the February 15 board meeting. Ackerman assumes his new position effective August 1. He will replace Ken Phillips, who recently announced his resignation. Ackerman has been employed by the district since 1975, has served in various administrative capacities including elementary principal, elementary supervisor, and for the past three years, has been administrative assistant. The school board also approved the following employees and volunteers for the 2000-2001 academic year; Kimberly  Warner is now a substitute contract driver. ben Duvall, teacher, Powhatan Elementary, received a supplemental contract for $75 for Teacher in Charge. The following individuals were approved as volunteers: Monroe Central High School -- Trevor Friday, Jeff Stevens; baseball--Ted Brown        softball--Pete Polemeni; track--Steve Rufener; River  High School--Chad Amos    Deron Farnsworth, Dave Rose, Casey Rose, Jim Luikart; baseball--Jim Miller   Ryan Collins   Austin Straub   Alvin Thompson   Ben Frye; boys track--Jill Dietz    Steve Rufener; girls track--Terry Tisher   Dave Wright; softball--Janice Tisher. Lori Caldwell, developmentally handicapped teacher, Powhatan Elementary, was granted a medical leave of absence effective, February 5 through February 23. Caldwell will return to work February 26. The board accepted the resignation of Chacity Stoehr, administrative typist, central office, effective February 10. Officials will act upon expiring administrative contracts at the March 15 meeting. They Include: Wayne Smith, one year term; Phil Ackerman, two year term; Darren Cook, two year term; Michael Dotson, two year ; Sam Schumacher, two year term. All of the above contracts expire June 30.

Source: Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, February 22, 2001.

 

Ackerman, Phil

            Four employees of the Switzerland of Ohio School District have tendered notices of retirement, including Superintendent of schools Phil Ackerman.

Ackerman has submitted a letter serving as 'notification of my resignation...... effective July 31. He said this will allow ample time for the board to employ a superintendent, and allow for a smooth transition due to his retirement. Ackerman said it is his intent to retire on July 31. Retiring also are Rose Snively, Powhatan elementary, effective June 1; Jim Swisher, Beallsville High School, effective May 31; and Robert Willis, special education supervisor, effective July 31. In other personnel matters, the contract of Ken Phillips, assistant superintendent, has been renewed for a three year period, and Beallsville High Principal Todd Christman's contract has been renewed for three years.

Source: Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, April 21, 2005. Front page.

            Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Ackerman requests the honour of your presence at the marriage of their daughter, Phyllis Jean to Mr. Roger W. Claus on Saturday, the eighth of January, Nineteen hundred and seventy-two at two o'clock in the afternoon. Fellowship Hall, Lewisville, Ohio

Reception following the ceremony. Source--Wedding Invitation

Ackerman, Roy B.

Ackerman, Ruth Charlotte Berch  

             Ruth Ackerman Berch, 63, of West Newton died Monday, March 29, 1999 in IHS of Greater Pittsburgh, Greensburg. She was born November 10, 1935 in Donora, a daughter of the late Arthur and Gladys Phythyon Ackerman. During the early part of her career, she worked in special education and was involved in the program for the partially sighted and visually handicapped in Westmoreland County.  She retired as a kindergarten teacher at the West Newton Elementary School. Along with her husband, she owned Sewickley Pines Manor and B. B. T. & D. Inc. She was a member of Christ Lutheran Church, West Newton. She is survived by her husband of 40 years, Thomas P. Berch; two sons, Bryan T. Berch, and his wife Lisa at home, Barry T. Berch and his wife, Janice of Dayton, Ohio; six grandchildren: Brock, Nathaniel, Brittani, Alyssa, Zackery and Sara; a great-granddaughter, Maci; a niece Ardith Mauck and her husband Fred of Belle Vernon, and their son, Eric. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday at the J. William McCauley, Jr. Funeral Home, West Newton. Funeral service will be held in the funeral home Friday at 10:00 a.m. with the Reverend Allen R. Riethmiller officiating.  Interment in Westmoreland Memorial Park, Hemofield Township.

Ackerman, Samuel H.

            Serial Number: 3531014. Race: White. Residence: R. F. D. 1, Jerusalem, Ohio. Enlistment Division: National Army. Enlistment Location: St. Clairsville, Ohio.

Enlistment Date: July 22, 1918. Birth Place: Jerusalem, Ohio. Birth Date: August 22, 1895. Assigns Comment: 18 Company 4 Training Battalion 158 Depot Brigade to 8 August 1918; Company G 333 Infantry to 7 October 1918; Company G 364 Infantry to Discharge Private American Expeditionary Forces 2 September 1918 to 2 April 1919. Ackerman, Thelma and Mr. Leighton Weber                  

            Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Thelma Ackerman and Leighton Weber. The wedding was quietly solemnized Saturday morning, December 15th, 1931, in the Lutheran parsonage at Wheeling, West Virginia.

Mrs. Weber is the attractive daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman and Mr. Weber is the elder son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Weber of near Oaklawn Avenue, Woodsfield, Ohio. He is employed at Drums garage. Many friends extend congratulations. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, December 31, 1931.

 

Ackerman, Walter J. and Alberta Mae Stephen 

             Miss Alberta Stephen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Stephen, of Woodsfield, Route 3, became the bride of Mr. Walter J. Ackerman, son of Mr. Benjamin Ackerman, of Lewisville, on Saturday morning November ninth, at nine o'clock. The wedding took place in St. John's Church of Miltonsburg at a Nuptial High Mass, with Reverend Noah E. Brunner officiating. Miss Dorothy Stephen, of Columbus, sister of the bride, was the maid of honor and Mr. Francis Weisend, of Lewisville, a close friend of the groom, served as best man. The bride chose a floor length gown of White satin with a net overskirt, fashioned with a sweetheart neckline, fitted bodice and three quarter length sleeves. Her fingertip veil was held in place with a coronet of seed pearls. She carried a pearl rosary, a gift of the groom, and wore a corsage of White carnations and red Roses. The maid of honor wore a blue satin floor-length gown with a net overskirt and her corsage was of White carnations and Roses. She wore matching flowers in her hair. The groom wore a teal blue suit and the best man a navy blue. Each had a White carnation in his lapel. A wedding dinner was served at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Carpenter. Guests present were Reverend Noah Brunner, of Miltonsburg; Mr. and Mrs. George Ackerman and son Wayne, of Parkersburg, West Virginia; Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller and family, Mrs. Elizabeth Poulton, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winland and daughter Joyce, of Barnesville; John Ackerman, Benjamin Ackerman and Francis Weisend, of Lewisville; Dorothy Stephen of Columbus; Mr. and Mrs. Marion Stephen and family, Woodsfield, Route 3; the host and hostess, Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Carpenter; and the honored guests, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ackerman. In the evening a reception was held in the Miltonsburg Parish Hall.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, November 21, 1946.

 

Ackerman, Walter John

            Walter J. Ackerman, 79, of 33133 Skin Creek Road, Lewisville, Ohio, died November 5, 1999, at his home. He was born near Lewisville, Malaga Township, on February 6, 1920, (parents: Benjamin P. Ackerman and Elsie Louise Hines). He was a very active dairy farmer for many years and was a member of St. John the Baptist Catholic Church, Miltonsburg, Ohio, where he had served on the Parish council for many years. He was also a member of the Knights of Columbus and the Holy Name Society and a 35 year member of the A. S. C. S. Surviving are his wife of 52 years, Alberta Mae Stephen Ackerman, whom he married November 9, 1946; three brothers, George B. Ackerman, of Parkersburg, West Virginia, Edward H. Ackerman, of Lewisville, Lester C. Ackerman, of Woodsfield; a sister, Leota Christman Buss, of Apple Creek; several nieces and nephews.

Friends were received at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, November 8. Funeral liturgy with Mass was celebrated November 9 at St. John the Baptist Catholic Church, Miltonsburg, with Monsignor Thomas C. Petronek as celebrant.

Burial followed in St. John the Baptist Catholic Cemetery, Miltonsburg. Vigil services were held November 8 at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to St. John the Baptist Catholic Church, 35560 Miltonsburg-Calais Road, Woodsfield, Ohio 43793.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, November 1999.

 

Ackerman, William and Mary Christman

            William Ackerman, age 54, of Monroe County. Parents: Paulus and Catharine Swainsberry Ackerman. Married October 11, 1910 to Mary M. Christman, age 37, of Monroe County. Daughter of Jacob and Catharine Pfalzgraf Christman. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Ackerman, William

             William Ackerman, age 73, (born: August 29, 1856) one of Woodsfields highly respected citizens, passed away Sunday evening, June 22, 1930, at 6:00 oclock at his home on the Woodsfield-Lewisville Road, after several weeks illness of intestinal ailment. Surviving are his widow, one son and one daughter as follows: Raymond Ackerman and Celeste, both of the home; two brothers and two sisters; besides a host of other relatives and friends who mourn his departure. Deceased was well and favorably known throughout the County, having resided at this place practically all of his life. He was a devout member of St. Pauls Evangelical Church and was a member of the Odd Fellows Lodge for the past forty years. Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon at St. Pauls Evangelical Church conducted by his pastor, the Reverend Otto C. Meyer. Interment was made in the Oaklawn cemetery in Woodsfield. They were largely attended, hundreds of friends and relatives being present. Members of the I. O. O. F. Lodge carried flowers, served as pall bearers, and conducted their final ritualistic service at the cemetery. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Wednesday, June 25, 1930. Death records: Volume number: 6335. Certificate number: 37999.

Ackerman, William G.

            William G. Ackerman, 50, of Woodsfield, died unexpectedly Saturday evening, August 7, 1976, at his home following an apparent heart attack. Born at Woodsfield, September 22, 1925, he was the son of Mrs. Jessie Ackerman, of Woodsfield, and the late William Ackerman. Mr. Ackerman was a partner in the Ackerman Brothers Garage in Woodsfield. He was a member of St. Pauls United Church of Christ, Woodsfield Lodge No. 338, Knights of Pythias, and Monroe Post No. 87, American Legion, all of Woodsfield. He was a veteran of World War II.

Surviving are his mother; his wife, Jean Hamilton Ackerman; two daughters, Mrs. Loren (Connie) Rothacher, of Sardis, Ohio, Route 2, and Mrs. Roger (Diane) Leasure, of Lewisville, Ohio, Route 1; one brother, Harold Ackerman, of Woodsfield; three sisters, Mrs. Eloise Smith, of Woodsfield; Mrs. Ruth Farmer, in England, and Mrs. Helen Strickling, of Woodsfield; one grandchild, and several nieces and nephews. Friends were received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home. Services were held in the Bauer and Turner Funeral Chapel on Wednesday afternoon at one oclock, with the Reverend Gene Kraus officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, August 12, 1976.

Adair, Sarah Louisa (nee Carpenter)                   

            Sarah Louisa Adair, 88, was found dead at her home, 1301 Blaine Avenue, Friday (March 27, 1981) about 3:30 P.M. She had been in failing health

for some time. She was born August 15, 1892, in Monroe County, daughter of Arias and Sarah E. Morris Carpenter. Her husband, Waldo Kenneth Adair, died May 28, 1959. She was a member of Westminster United Presbyterian Church and the American Legion Auxiliary. She leaves a brother, I. O. (Bob) Carpenter and a sister, Olive Mull both of Whipple. Friends may call Sunday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. at Scott-Atkinson Funeral Home, where the funeral will be Monday at 1 P.M. with the Reverend Philip Fletcher officiating. Burial will be in Northwood Cemetery on Saturday. Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, March 28, 1981.

Adair, Vernon Ray, Jr.

            Woodsfield, Ohio - Pvt. Ray Adair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Adair of West Marietta, has the following address: 35760080 785th Engns. P. D. Co. 6th Prov. Trans. Regt., Camp Clairbourne, Louisana. Source: The Zanesville Signal, Zanesville, Ohio, Wednesday, October 6, 1943, page 5.

            Woodsfield-Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Adair received a telegram from their son, Lt. Ray Adair saying he had landed in San Francisco and expects to see them soon. He has served 21 months in the Pacific theater in operations. Source: The Zanesville Signal, Zanesville, Ohio, Wednesday, January 16, 1946, page 3.

            Woodsfield-Vernon Ray Adair, Jr. of Camp Clairbourne, Louisiana, has been promoted to the rank of Technician Firth Grade. He recently spent a 12-day furlough with his parents and other relatives of Woodsfield and Barnesville. His address is 35760080, 785th Engineers, Pet. Dist. Co. 6th Prov. Trans. Regt., Camp Clairbourne, Louisiana. Source: The Zanesville Signal, Zanesville, Ohio, Monday, January 24, 1944, page 3.

               

Adair, Waldo Kenneth         

            Waldo Kenneth Adair, 1301 Blaine Avenue, died suddenly at 3:30 A.M.

Thursday at his home. He had been in failing health several months, but

death was unexpected. A former employee of the Cambridge Tin Mill and pump operator at the Cambridge Waterworks Plant. He was born June 6, 1893, in Lore City, the son of Jasper and Jennie Bell Adair. He leaves his widow, Sarah Louise Adair; one nephew, Waldo Adair of Zanesville. Two sisters and one brother preceded him in death. Mr. Adair was a veteran of World War I and was a member of the American Legion Post 84, Highway Patrol Auxiliary, and Odd Fellows Lodge. Funeral services will be conducted Monday at 1 P.M. at Scott Funeral Home by Reverend Thomas Wayman. Burial will be in Northwood Cemetery. Calling hours are 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Thursday, May 28, 1959.

Adams, Charles

             Charles Adams, 71, a retired carpenter, died at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Rogers in Summerfield, last Thursday forenoon. He was the son of James and Nancy Adams and was born in Monroe County. One grandson, Edward Adams, of Summerfield, is the only survivor. Funeral services, conducted by Rev. T. Sanford Williams, of Caldwell, were held in the Palestine Church of Christ, near Summerfield, Saturday morning, with burial in the Palestine Cemetery, in charge of the Murphy Funeral Home at Caldwell.

Source: Noble County Leader, February 26, 1942.

Adams, Gary R.

            Gary R. Adams, 66, of Reader, Wetzel County, died Wednesday, April 26, 2000, in Porters Falls, West Virginia as a result of an auto accident. He was a retired employee of Consolidated Aluminum of Hannibal Ohio, and a Protestant by faith. He was a member of the Masonic Lodge Number 39 A.F. & A.M. of New Martinsville, the Osiris Temple of Wheeling, a member of the Loyal Order of Moose Lodge Number 931 of New Martinsville, and he received the Pilgrim Degree of the Moose Lodge. He was preceded in death by his parents, Harry and Bertha Anderson Adams; two brothers, Jack Adams and Joe Adams; a sister, Faye Perham; a grandson, Mitchel Thomas Fluharty. Surviving are his wife, Roma June Haught Adams; a son, Rick Adams and his wife, Rita of New Martinsville; two daughters, Mrs. Tom "Debbie" Fluharty of Pine Grove, and Mrs. Mark "Kim" Henderson of Reader; eight grandchildren, Mrs. Rob "Leslie" Scott and her husband, Rob, Ashley Adams, Michael Fluharty, Joe Weaver, Sasha Rial, Kelsie Henderson, Derrick Adams and Alex Henderson. Friends received 2-9 p.m. today at Palmer Funeral Home, where services will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday. Interment in Knights of Pythias Cemetery, Pine Grove. Graveside services will be held by the Moose Lodge of New Martinsville.

Source: Wetzel County Message Board, West Virginia. Published: April 2000.
