Adams, Joseph G.

            Lewisville, Ohio-Joseph G. Adams, 42, of 32711 Christman Ridge Road died Saturday (April 24, 2004) at his home. He was born April 5, 1962, in Cleveland to Joseph G. and Delores Josephine Stazione Adamovich. He was a self-employed laborer and a member of Calais Church at Calais, Ohio. He is survived by his father of Middleburg Heights, Ohio; two sisters, Pamela J. Samuel of Parma, Ohio, and Cynthia A. Adamovich of Texas; two nieces; and one nephew. He was preceded in death by his mother. There is no visitation. Services and burial will be held at the convenience of the family. Arrangements by Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, May 6, 2004

 

Adams, Josiah S. and Hannah M. Bigley

            Married: February 28, 1891. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Adams, Lawrence and Miss Freda Irene Carson                       

            Miss Freda Irene Carson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Carson, 612 Front Street, Marietta, Ohio, became the bride of Mr. Lawrence Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Adams, of Rinard Mills, Ohio, on Sunday afternoon, July sixth, when vows were exchanged at half after two oclock. Reading the double-ring ceremony in the presence of the two families and guests was the Reverend Virgil E. Myers, performing the solemnization of vows in the First Congregational Church, Marietta, Ohio. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, August 11, 1947 (Lawrence Adams was a faculty member of the Lewisville High School, Lewisville, Ohio.)

Adams, Ransal Guy

            Ransel Guy Adams, 79, of Beallsville, Ohio, formerly of Pine Grove, West Virginia, died Thursday, September 16, 1999, in the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, Woodsfield, Ohio. He was a member of Pipefitters and Welders Local Union 152, Morgantown, West Virginia, and a member of Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, Barnesville, Ohio. He was preceded in death by his parents, Rexie Guy and Ella Flynn Adams. Surviving are his wife, Frances Watson Adams; five sons, Mark and David "Mike", both of Powhatan Point, Nathan, Tim and Rob, all of Beallsville; four daughters, Susan Green of Zanesville, Mary Thornberry of Beallsville, Cathy McCort of Barnesville, and Debra Hendershot of Woodsfield; two brothers, Rodman Adams of Wintersville, Ohio, and Rex Adams of Pine Grove, West Virginia; 24 grandchildren; eight great-grandchildren. Funeral services were held at 1 p.m. Saturday at the Harper Funeral Home, 52728 Ohio Avenue, Beallsville, Ohio.

Source: Wetzel County Message Board, West Virginia, September 1999.

Adams, W. H.

            W. H. Adams, aged 67 years, died at his home in Bellaire, Ohio February 21, 1916, from a complication of diseases.

            Deceased was a native of Woodsfield and the father of Mr. Arch Adams and Miss Ella Adams and a brother of Mr. James Adams and Mr. Thomas Adams. He also leaves a wife and several children by his second marriage.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, March 2, 1916.

            Born: September 27, 1899, died: May 1978, residence: Woodsfield

Adams, William

            William Adams, aged 27 years, son of Thomas Adams, was run over by a train at Pittsburg on Saturday and instantly killed. The remains were brought to Woodsfield on Tuesday and interred in the Woodsfield cemetery on Wednesday forenoon. He leaves his father, one brother and one sister.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, March 2, 1916.

Adamson, William G.         

             William G. Adamson, 66, of 109 East Marietta Street, died Tuesday night, February 18, 1964, at 11:30 oclock, in Barnesville General Hospital where he had been a patient since December 12.  He was born at Bloomfield, October 13, 1897, a son of Alfred and Mattie Thomas Adamson. Mr. Adamson was a retired farmer and oil field worker. He was a member of the Masterton Masonic Lodge at Lebanon. Surviving are his wife, Torin Morrison Adamson, and two sisters, Mrs. Lois McGillian and Mrs. Myrtle Karcher, of New Matamoras.   Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home where Masonic services will be held this Thursday evening at 8:00 oclock.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, February 1964.

Ady, Daniel C.         

            Funeral services for Daniel C. Ady, 74, of 4155 Johnson Road, Norton, Ohio, were held Tuesday afternoon at two oclock, in the Myers Funeral Home, at Barberton, with the Reverend Glenn Lockard officiating. Burial was in Greenlawn Cemetery. Mr. Ady died Friday evening, February 25, 1966, in Barberton Citizens Hospital after a brief illness.  A native of Cameron, Monroe County, Ohio, he was a cement mason, worked for Ohio Injector Company at Wadsworth for ten years and was a shoe salesman. Mr. Ady was a member of Wadsworth Aerie 2117 of Eagles and District 361, Greater Beneficial Union.  Surviving are his wife, Minnie Shafer Ady; three sons, Robert Ady, of the home; Roy Ady and Daniel Ady, of Barberton; two daughters, Mrs. Mary Mosgrove of Wadsworth, and Mrs. Doris Furman, of Barberton; one brother, Charles Youst, of Wadsworth; two sisters, Mrs. Oliver Fruth, of Tiffin, and Sister Magdalene St. Arsenius, of Wheeling, West Virginia, and twelve grandchildren.

Ady, Rachel A. Ault              

                Woodsfield, Ohio - Rachel A. Ault, 99, of Woodsfield died Sunday (February 19, 1995) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. She was born June 10, 1895, in Monroe County to William and Rebecca Palmer Ady. She was a member of Woodsfield Church of Christ. She was preceded in death by her husband, Stephen Ault, in 1951; two sons, Lester Ault, in 1940 and Floyd Ault in 1993; one daughter, Vera McConnell in 1982; one brother, Oscar Ady; three grandsons, Stephen, Virgil and Larry Ault; and one great grandson, Bruce McConnell. Mrs. Ault is survived by five sons, Ralph Ault. Stanley Ault, Clyde Ault and Chester Ault, all of Woodsfield, and Hilbert Ault of Barnesville; two daughters, Sylvia Jones and Erma Jones, both of Woodsfield; one sister, Ethel Grodhaus of Shadyside; 33 grandchildren; 78 great grandchildren and 30 great, great grandchildren. Services are 10 a.m. tomorrow at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield with ministers Harry Summers, John Hamilton, Keith Jones and Richard Harris officiating. Burial is in Cameron Cemetery. Friends will be received at the funeral home from 2 to 9 p.m. today.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, February 1995.

Ady, William C.

                Military records: Serial number, 2111582. Residence: Cameron, Ohio. Enlistment division: National Army. Enlistment location: Woodsfield, Ohio. Enlistment date: 04 October 1917. Birth place: Monroe County, Ohio. Age at time of enlistment: 29 7/12/ years. Assignments: 13 Company 4 Training Battalion to 11 November 1917; Company C 386 Battalion to 1 June 1918; 22 Company 6 Train Battalion 162 Depot Brigade to 17 June 1918; Company D 22 Battalion to 2 August 1918; 64 Company 16 Battalion 165 Depot Brigade to Discharge. Private Honorable discharge: 19 September 1918. Surgeons Certificate of Disability, 33 1/3 percent disabled. Date of death: April 4, 1960. Volume: 16112. Certificate: 25733. Married: yes. Place of death: Bellaire, Belmont County, Ohio. Residence: Monroe County. Age: 72. Source: Military records and Social Security index.

Affolter, David and Anna Conger

                David Affolter, age 28, of Monroe County. Parents: Jacob, Sr. and Margaret Palmer Affolter. Married: October 12, 1902 to Anna Conger. Age: 19. of Monroe County. Daughter of David and Jane Hughes Conger.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Name: David Affolter

Source: The Spirit of Democracy

Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, March 30, 1922

 Relatives were notified of the sudden death of David Affolter at Gridley, Kansas, last Monday, as a result of neuralgia of the heart. Mr. Affolter who is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Affolter of Jackson Ridge, and was well and favorably known in Woodsfield, where he was at one time located. He was a married man and his wife and family were located at Logan, Ohio, and they wrere arranging to join Mr. Affolter in Kansas when word of his death was received.

 The remains will be brought to Woodsfield and laid to rest in the family lot in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.

Agan, Asher

and Cassa Jackson

Source: The Spirit of Democracy

Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, October 11, 1870

 Asher Agan and Cassa Jackson, both of Center township, Monroe County, Ohio, were married September 29, 1870, by John Hamilton, J. P. 

 

Agey, Birdie Florence (nee Mann)   

                Mrs. Birdie Florence Agey, aged 42 years, wife of Charles Agey, of Irrville, Ohio, died at the Good Samaritan Hospital, Zanesville, Ohio, at 1 a.m. Saturday morning, April 10, 1920, following an operation for complication of diseases. She was admitted to the hospital on March 26th. Mrs. Agey was a member of the M. E. Church, a member of the Eastern Stars and a worker in the W. C. T. U. She leaves her husband, three children, Crystal Illores, Chester Glenn and Wilford Lloyd, all of the home, her mother, Mrs. Margaret Mann, of this place. The remains were brought Monday noon to the home of her mother on North Main Street, where funeral services were held Tuesday, conducted by the Reverend George L. Davis, pastor of the M. E. Church, and interment was made in the Ozark cemetery. The family has the sympathy of the entire community in their bereavement. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, April 15, 1920.

Agin, Charles E.

                Woodsfield-Charles Edward Agin, 71, of Woodsfield Route 2 died Monday morning near his home. (October 21, 1963). Mr. Agin, who had been having heart trouble, was born October 8, 1892, near Woodsfield, a son of the late David and Mary Twinem Agin. He was a World War I veteran. Surviving are five sisters, Mrs. Grace Hupp and Mrs. Fay Briggs, both of Woodsfield, Mrs. Lula Anclone and Mrs. Cora Brown, both of New Philadelphia, and Mrs. Esther Blue of Beallsville, Ohio.

Source: The Times Recorder, Zanesville, Ohio, Tuesday, October 22, 1963.

 

Agin, Charlie O.

                Military records: Serial number: 3375518. Residence; R. F. D. 4, Woodsfield, Ohio. Enlistment division: National Army. Enlistment location: Woodsfield, Ohio. Enlistment date: 08 August 1918. Birth place: Woodsfield, Ohio.  Birth date: 26 December 1887. Assignments: Ambulance Company 2339 Sanitary Train to Discharge Private Honorable discharge 3 March 1919.

Agin, Elsie Gail, (nee Eberle)                           

                 Bucyrus, Ohio- Mrs. Elsie G. Agin, 65, of RD three, Bucyrus, died at 6:40 p.m. Friday in Bucyrus Community Hospital. She had a heart ailment and had been in ill health for five years. She had been a resident of the Bucyrus community for about seven years, coming there from Beallsville, Ohio. She was a member of Beallsville, Ohio Methodist Church. She was born June 27, 1897, in Beallsville, Ohio, the daughter of Louis and Artie Forman Eberle. On July 27, 1914, she married Albert S. Agin, who survives. Also surviving are 5 sons, John and Russell of North Robinson, Glen and Fred of Butler, and Emmit of RD three, Bucyrus, a daughter, Mrs. Bib Trout of Canton, two brothers, Forrest and Clifford of Beallsville, Ohio, a sister Mrs. Anna Hopton of Beallsville, Ohio, 27 grandchildren and a great-grandchild. Funeral services will be conducted at 2 p.m. Monday at Munz-Pirnstall Funeral Home in Bucyrus by the Reverend Donald E. Patterson pastor of North Robinson Evangelical United B. Church with burial in Oakwood Cemetery in Bucyrus. Friends may call at the funeral home Sunday afternoon and evening.

Source: The Marion Star, Marion, Ohio, Saturday, December 28, 1962, page 4.

Agin, Lawrence L.

                Lawrence L. Agin, 83, of Circleville, died November 23, 2004 in Berger Hospital. He was born July 17, 1921 in Woodsfield, Ohio, the son of Clyde and Tina (Moberly) Agin. He was a World War II Army Veteran and retired Greyhound Bus Driver. He was preceded in death by his parents, wife Jeraldine and brothers Carl and Calvin. He is survived by nephews, Terry, Kelly, Chris, Gary and Ronny; niece, Toni. Funeral service will be held 1 p.m. Saturday, November 27, 2004 at the Wellman Funeral Home, Circleville. Burial will be in Floral Hills Memory Gardens. Friends may call from 11 a.m. till the time of service on Saturday.  Source: Columbus, Ohio, Wednesday, November 24, 2004.

Agin, Lucille (nee Yerian)  

                Lucille Agin, 82, of Barnesville, died Saturday (July 29, 2000) at Barnesville Hospital, Barnesville, Ohio. She was born January 2, 1918, in Woodsfield, Ohio, daughter of the late Charles William and Lucy (Truax) Yerian. Mrs. Agin was a retired clerk for Cheffy Drugs of Barnesville and a member of East Main Street Church of Christ. She was preceded in death by her husband, Virgil F. Agin; three brothers, Nova, Russell and Glenn Yerian; two sisters, Wilma Brown and Luella Spence; and a great-grandson. She leaves a son, Gene Agin of Kissimmee, Florida.; two sisters, Mrs. John (Donna) McLeish of Howell, Michigan, and Paulette Gray of Barnesville; eight grandchildren; 18 great-grandchildren.

Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at Campbell-Plumly-Milburn Funeral Home, Barnesville, where services will be 11 a.m. Tuesday with Evangelist M. Gale Yoho officiating. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, July 31, 2000.

Agin, Rosena (nee Kindelberger)   

                Mrs. Rosena Agin, a life Long resident of Monroe County passed away at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Edgar Hall, on South Main Street, Thursday evening, December 23 at nine o'clock at the age of 83 years, ten months and nine days. She was born near Coats Station, a daughter of Fred and Christina Kindelberger. She was one of eight children all of whom preceded her in death except one sister, Mrs. O. R. Baker, of Wichita, Kansas. On September 10, 1885, she was united in marriage with Lewis Milton Agin who preceded her in death on June 18, 1927. To this union were born seven sons and three daughters. At the early age of seventeen she was confirmed in Saint Paul's Evangelical Church, later transferring her membership to the Neuhart Baptist Church where she remained faithful as long as health permitted. She leaves to mourn five sons and three daughters: Fred of Newark, Ohio; Charlie of the home; Mrs. Edgar (Lillie) Hall, of Woodsfield, with whom she made her home for the past three years; Clyde, of Circleville, Ohio; Roger of Norwich, Ohio; Mrs. Mark (Gladys) Nalley of Grandville, Michigan; and Mrs. Carroll (Grace) Bishop of Mansfield, Ohio, twins; and Arthur, of Grand Rapids, Michigan. Seventeen grandchildren and six great-grandchildren also survive. Two sons, George, age 16 and Harry, age 3 preceded her in death several years ago. Mrs. Agin bore her sickness with patience and with a smile for all. She was a kind and loving mother, always thoughtful of her children and others. She will be sadly missed by the children and all who knew her. Brief funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at the Schumacher Funeral Home with additional services at the Neuhart Baptist Church, Minister J. V. A. Traylor officiated. She was laid to rest in the Neuhart Cemetery. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, December 1948.

Akins, Homer C. and Bertha Rapking

Albanese, Lynn   

                Lynn Garnet Albanese, 55, of Woodsfield, died Thursday, May 22, 2003, at her home. She was born February 6, 1948, in Martins Ferry, a daughter of Ernest L. (Sr.) and Hazel V. Johnson Albanese. Lynn was a Special Education Teacher at the Monroe Achievement Center in Woodsfield, a member of the Buchanan Presbyterian Church in Lewisville where she was a member of the Session.  She graduated from the Union Local High School in 1966 and Ohio University in 1970. Lynn received a master's degree from Ohio University. Lynn is survived by her parents, residents of Lloydsville (Belmont), one son, Robert W. Balney of San Francisco, California; one daughter, Captain Shannon Stambersky and her husband, Lt. Peter, stationed in Baghdad, Iraq; one brother, Ernest L. Albanese, Jr. and his wife, Mary Ann of South Orange, New Jersey and one sister, Cynthia Peroni and her husband, Frank of Phoenix, Arizona. Family and friends will be received at the Beck-Altmeyer Funeral Home, 204 West Main Street, St. Clairsville, on Tuesday from 6 to 8 p.m., where services will be held on Wednesday at 11 a.m., with the Reverend Connie Garlique officiating. Interment will follow in the Union Cemetery in Saint Clairsville. For those who are unable to attend services, online condolences may be offered to the family at www.altmeyerfuneralhome. com.

Source: The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio, Tuesday, May 27, 2003.

Aldeman, William

                Died: April 24, 1927, Monroe County, Ohio. Volume number: 5337. Certificate number: 24525. Source: Monroe County death records.

 

Alden, Percival C.  

                Percival Charles Alden, 80, of 217 Harmar Street, Marietta, died Thursday evening, July 21, 1966, at 5:30 oclock, in Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born September 4, 1885, in Lower Salem, a son of the late Frank R. and Clara Hockenberry Alden. He was married November 20, 1910, to Caroline M. Bohl, who died May 26, 1961. Mr. Alden was employed in the maintenance department of Broughtons Farm Dairy until he retired in 1960. Two sons survive, Harry Alden and Clarence Alden, of Marietta, with nine grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Also surviving are one sister and one brother, Mrs. May Smith, of Athens, and John Alden, of Akron. One grandson, Philip, was killed in Germany May 28, 1963, and three brothers and one sister are deceased, Harry Pip and Reese Alden and Mrs. Elizabeth Flower. Funeral services were held Monday afternoon at 2:30 oclock in the Doudna & McClure Funeral Home, at Marietta. Interment was in Rainbow Cemetery.

                L. A. Alexander, age 31, of Pennsylvania. Residence: Sistersville, West Virginia. Parents: E. C. and Eva Ehrhart Alexander. Married: November 17, 1915 to Cora A. Stine. Age 26, of Monroe County. Daughter of William and Susanna Cline Stine. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Anderson, Marjorie, nee Stauffer

                Anderson, Marjorie B. , 88, of New Martinsville, West Virginia, died Tuesday, October 12, 2004, in Wetzel County Health Care Center, New Martinsville. She was born April 5, 1916, in Clarington, Ohio, the daughter of the late Frank and Carrie E. Arn Stauffer.  She was a 1936 graduate of Salem High School, Clarington, a retired employee of Herrick's IGA, New Martinsville, a member of the Zion United Methodist Church, Clarington, and a 50 year member of the Order of Eastern Star, Littleton Chapter 117 of Hundred, West Virginia and Chapter 50 of New Martinsville. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Willis G. Anderson in 1964, four brothers and five sisters. Surviving are several nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends on Friday, 4 to 8 p.m., at Grisell Funeral Home & Crematory, 751 Third Street, New Martinsville, where services will be held on Saturday at 11 a.m., with Reverend Richard Wilson officiating. Eastern Star services Friday at 7 p.m.  Interment will be at Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville. Memorial contributions can be made to Zion United Methodist Church, in care of-- Bonnie Logston, 48450 Cain Ridge Road, Clarington, Ohio 43915.

Source: The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio. Published: October 14, 2004.

Algeo, Annie S. and William H. Cordray

Algeo, Donal

                Algeo, Donald Paul "Duck" , 71, of Carrie Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Tuesday, November 9, 2004 in Wheeling Hospital. Don was born October 22, 1933 in Parkersburg, West Virginia, a son of the late Myron Ralph "Butch" and Nora Elizabeth Bowen Algeo. He was retired from former Quarto #4 Mine, Powhatan Point, and retired as maintenance foreman from the former Conalsco Plant in Hannibal, Ohio. He was a member of Masonic Lodge Moriah #105 Free & Accepted Masons, Powhatan Point, Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite Valley of Steubenville, a Methodist by faith and an accomplished woodworker and artist.

He was preceded in death by his first wife Patricia Ann Massie Algeo in 1980. Surviving are his wife, Ingrid I. Hill Algeo, two sons, Donald Wade (Kelly) Algeo of Powhatan Point, Ohio, James M. (Sabrina) Algeo of Reynoldsburg, Ohio; a daughter, Debra L. Baranich of Groveport, Ohio; a step son, Joe (Christy) Hill of Powhatan Point, Ohio; three stepdaughters, Carmen (Donald) Rhoades of Johnstown, Ohio, Debbie (Phillip) Archer of Woodsfield, Ohio and Regina Hill of Powhatan Point, Ohio; 16 grandchildren including his "little buddy" Westley, two great grandchildren; a brother, William (Debbie) Algeo of Humble, Texas, a sister, Shirley (William) Teare of Michigan City, Indiana; several nieces and nephews. Friends received Thursday, 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m., at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point, where services will be held at 1 p.m., Friday, with Reverend Rick Hendrix and Pastor Donald J. Cordery, officiating. Interment in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio. Masonic services will be held Thursday, 7 p.m., in the funeral home. Online condolences may be sent to the family at www.altmeyer.com.

Source: The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio. Published: November 10, 2004.

Allar, Tanya Sue and David William Bright

                May 20 is the wedding date chosen by Miss Tanya Sue Allar and David William Bright. Miss Allar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Allar and the late Nancy Lucas Allar, of Route 1, Jerusalem, Ohio, is employed at The First National Bank in Barnesville. She is a graduate of Beallsville High School. Mr. Bright, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bright of Route 3, Woodsfield, is a graduate of Skyvue High School and is manager of Riesbeck's in Woodsfield.

Alleman, Donald W. and Rita Sharmon, nee Coss

                Our daughter, Rita Sharmon, will be married to Donald W. Alleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Junior Alleman, on Sunday, the twenty-sixth of May, nineteen hundred and seventy-four, at two thirty o'clock in the afternoon, at the Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville, Ohio We invite you to worship with us, witness their vows and be our guest at the reception immediately following in the Church Social Room. If you are unable to attend, we ask your presence in thought and prayer. Mr. and Mrs. James T. Coss.  Source: Invitation card, 1974.

Alleman, Lloyd

                Lloyd W. Alleman, 78, of 42084 Alleman Road, Woodsfield, died April 19, 1995 at the home of his daughter, Mrs. William (Jean ) Mowder of Woodsfield. He was born in Monroe County, September 14, 1916, a son of the late John Alleman and Ella Reef Alleman. He was a retired farmer and timber cutter. He is survivied by one son, Ronald Alleman, Woodsfield; two daughters, Mrs. William (Jean) Mowder, Woodsfield and Mrs. Mark (Shirley) McCort, Burbank, Ohio; one brother, Roy Alleman , Woodsfield ; one sister, Rose Craig, Woodsfield; five grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his wife, Pauline Suppes Alleman on October 12, 1990; also three brothers, Raymond, Paul and Junior Alleman.

Friends were received April 21 at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services were held April 22 with Russell Eddy officiating. Interment in the Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield. Source: Monroe County Beacon,   Woodsfield, Ohio. Published: April 27, 1995.

                Married: August 9, 1894. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Alleman, Maria Anna and Bendight Iserli

                Married: February 10, 1876. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Alleman, Paul Kenneth

                Paul Kenneth Alleman, 69, of  Woodsfield, Route 1, died July 8 in the Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born November 25, 1913 in Monroe County, the son of the late John and Ellen Reef Alleman. He was a retired Monroe County employee. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Thomas Alleman; one son, Paul of Route 1, Woodsfield; one daughter, Mrs. Dean (Betty) Groves of Route 1, Woodsfield; three brothers, Roy Alleman and Lloyd Alleman, both of Woodsfield and Junior Alleman of Sardis; one sister, Mrs. Rosa Craig of Woodsfield; five grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. Mr. Alleman was preceded in death by a brother, Raymond Alleman, in May 1974. Source: Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio. Published--July 14, 1983.

Alleman, Roy L.

                 Roy L. Alleman, 70, of Woodsfield, died Friday (June 23, 2000) at Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville, West Virginia. He was born February 18, 1930, in Monroe County, a son of the late John and Ella Reef Alleman. He was retired from Ormet Corp. in Hannibal, Ohio. He is survived by his wife, Wilma Bertschy Alleman; a son, Roger Alleman of Woodsfield; three daughters, Karen Jones and Nancy McKelvey, both of Woodsfield, and Sandy Fontana of New Philadelphia; seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.                 There will be no visitation. Private graveside services will be 1 p.m. Monday in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, with Paul Eddy officiating. Arrangements are being handled by Bauer-Turner Funeral Home.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, June 24, 2000.

Allen, Charles A.

                Military records: Serial number: 2481522. Residence: Johnson Run, Ohio. Enlistment division: National Army. Enlistment location: Woodsfield, Ohio.

Enlistment date: 22 Jun 1918. Birth place: Clarington, Ohio.

Birth date: 24 April 1893. Assignments: 23 Co 6 Battalion 158 Depot Brigade to 15 July 1918; Co F 333 Infantry to 5 October 1918; Co I 364 Infantry to 22 October 1918; Co B 348 Infantry to Discharge Private Ypres-Lys: Meuse-Argonne; Defensive Sector. American Expeditionary Forces 2 September 1918 to 2 April 1919. Honorable discharge 25 April 1919.

Allen, Elizabeth Ann Miller (nee Tanner)        

                Woodsfield, Ohio  Elizabeth Ann Allen, 88, of Woodsfield, formerly of Perryville, Missouri, died Wednesday (June 13, 2001) at Barnesville Hospital, Barnesville, Ohio. She was born August 24, 1912, in Cleveland, daughter of the late Edward W. and Anna Richards (Butler) Tanner. Mrs. Allen was a former employee of Aultman Hospital, Canton, where she served in the housekeeping department. She was a Catholic by faith.  She was preceded in death by her first husband, Donald Miller; her second husband, William Allen; three sisters; and a brother. She leaves two daughters, Mrs. Jim (Patricia) Shaw of Woodsfield, and Mrs. Les (Mary Louise) Heinrich of Canton; a stepdaughter, Mrs. Harold (Patricia) Heaps of Perryville, Missouri; nine grandchildren; nine step-grandchildren; several great-grandchildren; several great-great-grandchildren. Friends may call from 7 to 9 p.m. today at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, and from 9 to 10:30 a.m. Monday at Miller Family Funeral Home, Perryville, Missouri. Mass of Christian burial will be 11 a.m. Monday at St. Vincent Catholic Church, Perryville, Missouri, with the Reverend Father Kevin Fausz C. M. serving as celebrant. Burial will be in Saint Boniface Cemetery, Perryville, Missouri. Memorial contributions may be made to Warm the Children, c/o Pandora Neuhart, 40189 Gun Club Road, Woodsfield, OH 43793.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, June 2001.

Allen, George W.

                George W. Allen, an aged and highly respected citizen of Woodsfield, died about 1:00 oclock this Thursday morning, April 14, 1932, at his home on West Marietta Street. He was nearly eighty years of age and had not been in good health for about a year. The death of his wife, Mahala C. Allen, on October 21st of last year was a severe shock and a loss he felt keenly every day thereafter.

We go to press too early to give details of the funeral which will be in charge of W. P. Galbraith. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, April 14, 1932 and the Monroe County death records. Volume number: 6897.

Certificate number: 25763.

 

Allen, Glenn F.

                New Matamoras - Glenn F. Allen, 85, of 912 Park Ave. Died Saturday (March 20, 2004) at Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born June 20, 1918, in Fly, Ohio to Benjamin Franklin and Etta P. Evans Allen. He retired from Corning Glass at Paden City, West Virginia, and was a member of New Matamoras Nazarene Church. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy V. Williamson Allen; one son, Donald P. (Dawn) Allen, Sr., Frostproof, Florida; one grandson, Donald P. Allen, Jr.; and one granddaughter, Terry Lynn Allen. He was preceded in death by his parents; two brothers, Harold and Raymond Allen; and two sisters, Myrtle Allen and Blanche Parr. Services are at 1 p.m. Wednesday at New Matamoras Nazarene Church with the Reverend David Hyde officiating. Burial is in Matamoras Cemetery. Calling hours are from 2 to 6 p.m. Tuesday at Myers Funeral Home in Sistersville, West Virginia and from noon to 1 p.m. Wednesday at the church. Source: The Marietta Times, Monday, March 22, 2004.

                Married: November 22, 1866. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Allen, John C. and Emma Barnes

                Married: October 15, 1872. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Allen, John F.

                John F. Allen, 78, passed away Tuesday morning, August 28, 1956, at 8:00 oclock, at his home, 101 Monroe Street, following an extended illness. A son of Reuben and Priscilla Cree Allen, he was born on Dent Ridge on August 5, 1878. He was a retired oil field pumper. Mr. Allen was a member of the Methodist Church and of the Mens Bible class. He was also a member of the Knights of Pythias Lodge for fifty-two years. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Freda L. Jackson Allen, one daughter, Mrs. Richard (Mildred) McFerren, of Waverly, Ohio; two grandsons, Richard Allen McFerren and Thomas Leslie McFerren; one great granddaughter, Diane Alison McFerren; one sister, Mrs. Grace Wilson, of Follansbee, West Virginia, and one brother, Ollie Allen, of Akron, Ohio. Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home. The Knights of Pythias held ritualistic services on Wednesday evening at 7:30 oclock at the funeral home. Funeral services will be held this Thursday afternoon at two oclock in the funeral chapel, with Reverend Charles Reed of Circleville, a former pastor, officiating. Interment will be in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

 

Allen, John F. and Freda L. Jackson

                John F. Allen, age 32, of Monroe County. Parents: Reuben and Penelope Cree Allen. Married: June 7, 1911 to Freda L. Jackson. Age: 21, of Monroe County. Daughter of W. T. and Amanda Devaul Jackson.

Source: Monroe County marriage records.

Allen, John W.

                John W. Allen, 92, of Woodsfield, died in Bellaire City Hospital Monday afternoon, October 31, 1966, at four oclock, following an illness. A retired farmer, he was born at Ripley, West Virginia, April 12, 1874. Surviving are four sons, Harley Allen, of Woodsfield, Route 4; Edward Allen, Chester Allen and Hershel Allen, of Ashland; two daughters, Mrs. Della Withrow, of Ashland, and Mrs. Clara Hogue, Woodsfield; one sister, Mrs. Loretta Rader, of Akron; ten grandchildren and several great grandchildren. His wife, Rebecca Allen, died in 1948. Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home. Funeral services will be held in their chapel on Friday afternoon at two oclock, with Minister J. V. A. Traylor officiating. Burial will be in the Mount Carrick Cemetery.

Allen, Mahala C. 

                 Mahala C. Allen died early on Wednesday morning, October 20, 1931, at her home on West Marietta Street. She had not been in good health for several months. Funeral services will be held on Friday, in charge of her pastor, the Reverend W. J. Jones, of the M. E. Church of which she was a devout member and regular attendant when health permitted. Short services at the home at 1:30 will be followed by final obsequies at the M. E. Church at 2:00 oclock. Interment will be made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield. Mrs. Allen is survived by her aged husband, George W. Allen, and several sons and daughters.  Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, October 21, 1931 and Monroe County death records. Volume number: 6736. Certificate number: 61541.

Allen Mary Jane (nee Stewart)                         

                Mary Jane Allen, 77, of Box 195, Woodsfield, Rt. 4, died January 17, 1988, at the Wetzel County Hospital in New Martinsville, West Virginia. She was born September 24, 1911 in Monroe County, a daughter of the late Daniel and Molly Hendershot Stewart. She was a member of the Mt. Olive Methodist Church.   She was preceded in death by her husband Harley Allen, December 1982 and also 4 brothers; Chester, John, James and Charles Stewart; three sisters, Daisy Stewart, Lula Mae Stewart and Lucinda Ault; one half-sister Susie Henthorn. She is survived by three daughters; Mrs. Clyde (Molly) Hupp of Woodsfield Route 4 , Mrs. Robert (Dorothy) Willis of Ashland and Mrs. Leander (Eva Jean) Hupp of Ashland; one son-Guy Allen of Martins Ferry; 8 grandchildren; 9 great grandchildren; two brothers- Oscar Stewart of Rittman and Burl Stewart of Bowerstown; two sisters Mrs. Clarence (Viola) Bertschy of West Salem and Della Day of McMechon, West Virginia. Burial was in Mt. Olive Church Cemetery.

Allen, Mildred M. (nee Byers)                            

                Sardis, Ohio - Mildred M. Allen, 86, of Seventh Avenue died Friday (April 12, 2002) at Wetzel County Hospital in New Martinsville, West Virginia. She was born February 18, 1916, in Monroe County to George E. and Mary Kathryn Merckle Byers. She was a retired Cook after 30 years with the Switzerland of Ohio School District and a retired custodian after 10 years with Citizens National Bank in Sardis. She was a member of the Community Club in Sardis and the Lutheran church in Trail Run. She was preceded in death by her husband, Raymond Allen; her parents; four brothers; and three sisters. She is survived by one son, Galen (Teresa) Allen of Sardis; one daughter, Carolyn (William) Gano of Sardis; three brothers, George Byers of Littleton, Colorado, David Byers of Macon, Georgia, and Paul Byers of Woodsfield; one sister, Phyllis Mae Yost of Palm Desert, California; and one grandson, William Gano of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Services are at 11 a.m. Tuesday at Grisell Funeral Home, 37234 Mound Street, Sardis, with the Reverend David Mansperger officiating. Burial is in New Matamoras Cemetery. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.

Source: The Marietta Times, Marietta, Ohio, April 15, 2002.

Allen, Wilma R. Lade (nee Slonaker)                             

                Chester, West Virginia - Wilma R. Lade Allen, 65, of Chester, West Virginia, died at 6 p.m. Saturday, (January 30, 1993) at Weirton Medical Center at Weirton, West Virginia. Mrs. Allen was born June 4, 1927, at Matamoras to Floyd and Nellie Flowers Slonaker. She was a Protestant. She was preceded in death by her husband, Logan in 1975; one brother, Willard Slonaker; and one sister, Bette Williams. Mrs. Allen is survived by two sons, Terry and Ron Allen of Lisbon; four daughters, Mrs. Jack (Kay) Raneri of Lisbon, Mrs. Edward (Carol) Dieterich of Woodsfield, Mrs. K. James (Shelly) Anderson of Chester, West Virginia, and Mrs. Kenneth (Janet Peach) Welling of Chester, West Virginia; two brothers, Bill Slonaker of Akron and Paul Slonaker of Matamoras; three sisters, Opal June Felton of Matamoras, Mrs. Bill (Dot) Motz of Canton, and Mrs. Jim (Norma Jean) Bush of Matamoras; nine grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. Reverend James Dumire of Chester First United Methodist Church will conduct private graveside services at the convenience of the family at Columbiana County Memorial Park in east Liverpool. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Lung Association. The Arner Funeral Chapel in Chester is in charge of arrangements.

Alvis, Mr. Vernon and Miss Catherine Weisend                           

                A wedding gown of lace over net and satin was worn by Miss Catherine Weisend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nick Weisend, of Lewisville, Route, for her marriage, June sixteenth, nineteen hundred fifty-one, to Mr. Vernon Alvis, whose parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Alvis, of Columbus, Ohio. The double ring ceremony took place at St. Josephs Church, Burkhart, Ohio, with the Reverend Joseph Finan officiating. The brides fingertip veil was held in place by a tiara of net and pearls. She carried a White prayer book topped with an orchid from which hung White satin streamers. The bridesmaid, Miss Rose Weisend, sister of the bride, was dressed in a yellow organdy over satin and carried a colonial bouquet of red and White Roses. Mr. James Weisend, brother of the bride, served as best man. The brides mother chose a blue silk dress. The bridegrooms mother also wore blue silk. Both mothers wore red Rose corsages. Immediately following the ceremony a dinner was served at the home of the brides brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Carpenter in Lewisville, Ohio. Later in the evening a dance was held in the Parish hall. The new Mrs. Alvis is a 1950 graduate of Lewisville high school and is now employed with Motorist Mutual Insurance Company at Columbus. Mr. Alvis was graduated from Rutland high school and is employed at General Motors in Columbus. Mr. and Mrs. Alvis are at home at 61 West 5th Avenue in Columbus.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, June 1951.

 

Alvis, John Michael

                John Michael Alvis, May 25, 1964-November 30, 2000. John's life was taken from him by an unknown assailant at his home in Azerbairy. He was born in Columbus, Ohio, and moved to the Woodlands, Texas with his family in 1984. John graduated from Texas A&M University with a degree in Political Science in 1988. At the time of his death he was a resident director of the International Republican Institute working to assist emerging democracies in their quest to develop open and free elections. He was a former regional political director for the Republican National Committee and chief strategist during Congressman Kevin Brady's first campaign. He was a respected political operative, managing several successful political campaigns including Steve Merrill's first campaign for the Governor of New Hampshire. He is survived by his parents, Vernon and Catherine Alvis of The Woodlands, Texas; his brothers, Mark and Keith Alvis and their families of The Woodlands, Texas; his sister, Deborrah Reid and her family of Montgomery, Texas; and numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. John loved his work, but his greatest passion was his family, his Dalmatian, Jersey and his many friends and associates. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the John Alvis Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Scott Howell & Co., Inc., 2211 North Lamar St., Suite 100, Dallas, Texas 75202.

Source: The Columbus Dispatch, January 6, 2001.

 

Alwine, Charles

                Quaker City, Ohio-Charles Alwine, 65 of Quaker City Route three, died Thursday morning, July 16, 1976, of an apparent heart attack. Alwine was born October 5, 1910. He was a farmer and a member of the Methodist Church in Quaker City. He is survived by his wife, Mabel, of the home; his mother, Mrs. Frank (Roena) O'Conner Alwine of Quaker City; three daughters, Mrs. John (Mary Ann) Davis of Texas, Mrs. Jim (Leota) Galford of Sundbury and Mrs. Eugene (Janice) A. Canel of California; a son, Frank Clifford of New Concord; three sisters, Mrs. Roy (Mary) Frame of Lore City, Mrs. Dean (Marie) Burget of Toledo and Mrs. Pard (Martha) Kent of Columbus; and seven grandchildren. Friends may call at Eberle Funeral Home in Quaker City from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday. Services are 1:30 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home with burial in Friends Cemetery, Quaker City.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, July 1976.

 

Alwine, Frank Clifford         

                 Quaker City - Services will be 11 a.m. Thursday at Thorn-Black Funeral Home, Quaker City, for Frank Clifford "Cliff" Alwine, 50, of Quaker City, who died Monday (January 20, 2003) at Barnesville Hospital Emergency Room. The Reverend Carol Touvell will officiate.  Burial will be in Friends Cemetery.  Military graveside services will be conducted by the Guernsey County Veterans Council. Friends may call from 2 to 9 p.m. today (Wednesday) at the funeral home. He was born January 27, 1952, in Millwood Township, Guernsey County, son of the late Charles C. and Mabel Irene (Miller) Alwine. Mr. Alwine was a former employee of NCR.  He was co-owner of Lingo's Hardware, and owner of Temp-Trol Air Conditioning.  He was also a self-employed farmer. He was a former member of the Cornerstone Assembly of God Church in Barnesville. He loved hunting and spending time with his friends. He was a 1970 graduate of Zane Trace High School, and a member of the National Guard during the Vietnam Era.

He leaves three daughter, Mrs. Greg (Angel) Lake of Fairview, Mrs. Shawn (Chasity) Lake of Quaker City and Heather Alwine of Zanesville; his former wife, C. J. Mellon Troy of Zanesville; three sisters, Leota Alwine (Fred McKinney) of Quaker City, Mary Ann Davis of Richardson, Texas, and Mrs. Eugene (Janice) Canel of Granada Hills, California; two aunts, Martha White and Naomi White, both of Columbus; seven grandchildren, Desiree Alwine, Bobby Alwine, Corey Lake, Chandra Lake, Carissa Lake, Spencer Lake and Caden Lake; two nieces and three nephews; and several cousins. Source: The Daily Jefferson Newspaper, Cambridge, Ohio, Wednesday, January 22, 2003, p. A6.

Amos, Doris Ruth and Edward Dale Latimer

                Vows of marriage were repeated in a double ring ceremony Saturday afternoon, July fifteenth, at four oclock uniting Miss Doria Ruth Amos and Edward Dale Latimer, both of Woodsfield. White gladioli arranged with fern and lighted candelabra arranged at the altar of the First Methodist church in Woodsfield provided the background for a pretty summer wedding which was performed by the Reverend William M. Miller. As guests arrived to be seated Mr. Gene Huffman offered a medley of organ music including At Dawning and Through The Years. He also accompanied Miss Mary Emma Traylor, soloist, who sang The Sweetest Story Ever Told and The Lords Prayer. Ushering were Dan Feasel of Akron, Ohio and Donald Armstrong of Solana Beach, California. As the Lohrengrin Bridal chorus was played the wedding party entered the church. The bride was preceded to the altar by Mrs. Lucian Weber who served as her matron of honor and only attendant. She was attired in a street length gown of powder blue with matching hat and mitts. She carried a loose bouquet of yellow roses. The bride was attired in a ballerina length gown of embossed white organdy, detailed with a short cuffed sleeve, slightly rolled V-neck collar and bouffant skirt complemented with matching white puritan bonnet accented with elbow length white illusion veiling. She carried a white prayer book topped with a white orchid from which dell white satin steamers. Her only jewelry was a single strand of pearls, a gift of the groom. As they approached the altar they were met by the bridegroom and his best man, Mr. Lucian Weber, followed by the ushers. Following the ceremony the bridal party was honored with a dinner at the home of the brides mother before leaving on a short honeymoon. The new Mrs. Latimer traveled in a light beige Handmacher suit with brown accessories and a white orchid corsage. The bride, the oldest daughter of Mrs. Edmund Brubach, of High street, is a graduate of Woodsfield high school and after graduation attended Martins Ferry hospital school of nursing. The groom, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. R. Latimer, of High street, was graduated from Woodsfield high school and Marietta college. At the present time he is enrolled at Kent State University.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, July 1950.

Amos, Helen M.  

                Miss Helen M. Amos, 40, of Marietta, Route 1, died Friday morning, May 10, 1963, at 1:30 oclock in Marietta Memorial Hospital after a Long illness. She was born in New Matamoras October 25, 1922, a daughter of Oscar Amos and the late Millie Hall Amos. She spent most of her life in New Matamoras. In addition to her father she is survived by her stepmother, Stella Amos; one brother, Robert Amos, of Plainville, Kansas, and several aunts and uncles. Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at two oclock, at the Corum Funeral Home, in New Matamoras. Interment was in the New Matamoras Cemetery.

 

Amos, Jack S.     

                Woodsfield, Ohio  Jack S. Amos, 73, of New Matamoras R.D. 1, died Wednesday (January 9, 2002) at his home. He was born April 8, 1928, in New Matamoras, son of the late Arch and Irene Cochran Amos. He was a retired iron worker and a Protestant by faith. He was preceded in death by his wife, Janena Beaver Amos, in 1999, and a brother, Robert Amos. He leaves two sons, Dennis Amos of Tuscaloosa, Alabama, and Tom Amos of Sardis; a daughter, Jane Kinsey of New Matamoras; a brother, Don Amos of New Matamoras; two sisters, Helen Amos of Summerfield and Ruth Ann Heiney of New Matamoras; nine grandchildren. Graveside services will be 11 a.m. Saturday at New Matamoras Cemetery with the Reverend Frank Conley officiating. Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, is handling the arrangements.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, January 2002

 

Amos, James L. and Millie P. Martin

                Married: December 31, 1897. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Amos, J. O.

                 General James O. Amos passed away at his home on North Ohio Avenue, Saturday at four o'clock. Thursday morning about nine o'clock he was taken with an attack of acute indigestion. Later in the day lobar pneumonia developed and forty-eight hours later he passed away. While frail owing to his advanced age he has been in his usual health and had been at his desk at The News and Democrat office for weeks up until the day of his final sickness. He was born on a farm near Beallsville, Ohio, Monroe County, Ohio, March 30, 1833. His ancestors were with those who settled with Lord Baltimore in Maryland in 1629, and his parents in their youth crossed the mountains of Virginia in wagons on their emigration to Ohio. He continued to reside on the farm until reaching the age of manhood receiving the education and training usually given a farmer's son in those days. He taught school a portion of the time between the ages of eighteen and twenty-seven. Having decided upon the profession of law he prosecuted his studies at home and was admitted to the bar at the age of twenty-seven and two years later was elected to the position of prosecuting attorney of Monroe County, in which position he served two terms. He was elected and served two terms in The State Senate from the 19th district composed of the counties of Monroe, Guernsey, and Noble. During this period while practicing law he also served for ten years as school examiner for Monroe County. After coming to Shelby County he served as County school examiner for a number of years. In 1874, when that notable character, William Allen, was elected Governor of Ohio, he called General Amos as his assistant by appointing him Adjutant General. During that term he organized The National Guard of the state and effected on an agreement with the Ordnance Department at Washington whereby The Ohio National Guard was first furnished with modern arms. In January 1876, General Amos moved to Sidney and bought The Shelby County Democrat. The forty-three years which have passed since he assumed active control of the paper were years of hard work and serious study by the deceased in the interest of the community which he sought to serve. In The Democrat and Daily News his every endeavor was to make a good paper, one that would add to the social standing, general intelligence and information of the reader with a disposition to injure none. Always a forceful writer, his honesty and democracy were never questioned. During the forty-three years spent in the newspaper field in Sidney, he was a familiar figure at The National and State Press Association meetings, as well as in The State and District Political Conventions, in all of which his counsel was sought and in many of which meetings he held positions of honor. In 1891 he was elected to The State Senate from the 12th Senatorial District enjoying thereby the honor of having served two different districts of the state in that body. He was for many years interested in the financial institutions and many of the manufacturing industries of this city in the capacity of stockholder and member of board of directors. His identification with these enterprises was more from the purpose of encouraging the growth of Sidney than from a personal object. He was a member of The Masonic Orders and I. O. O. F. and in earlier years took a most lively interest in the work of other orders. As a member of The M.E. Church, he was always found in his seat at the Sunday morning service unless sickness prevented. His home life was ideal, very fond of his home and family, he was never so happy as when surrounded by them in their frequent gatherings. His devotion to his wife was beautiful and her loss is a deep personal one. His place in the home can never be filled and only the kindness of time can soften the blow his family feels. On September 9, this year, he and his devoted wife celebrated their sixty-second wedding anniversary, surrounded by all their children, all of whom are living; namely, Mrs. Emma Pegg, of Columbus; Mrs. Horace Holbrook, of Warren; Clara and Katherine and W. T., E. C., and Howard A. Amos of this city, and F. C. Amos, of Columbus. Simplicity marked his every step, while a kind word he had for all. He loved nature and took great interest in its development for he was himself one of nature's own true nobleman. Of him we may say:

"Life's work well done;

                                                                                Life's race well run;

                                                                                "Life's crown well won;

                                                                                Now comes rest."

Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, December 26, 1918.

 

Amos, Mary E. and George B. Clingan

                Married October 15, 1867. Source: Monroe County, Ohio marriage records.

Amos, Oliver R.

                Oliver R. Amos, 83, of Scio, died Thursday evening, February 9, 1967, at the Sunny Slope Nursing Home, Bowerston, after an extended illness. He was born September 30, 1883, in Perry Township, Harrison County, a son of Sanford and Agnes Amos. Mr. Amos was a livestock dealer, auctioneer and wool broker.

Surviving are his wife, Clara, whom he married January 25, 1905; three sons, Harold Amos, of Somerton; Hubert Amos and Jack Amos, of Scio; one daughter, Mrs. Kenneth (Agnes) Timmons, of Barnesville; eight grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at two oclock in the Purviance Funeral Home, at Scio, with Reverend S. V. Huffman and Reverend Jay Crites officiating. Interment was in Perrysville Cemetery.

Amos, Virgil E.

                New Matamoras, Ohio - Virgil E. Amos, 73, of Williamson Avenue, died at 12:05 a.m. Friday (January 3, 1977) at Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born October 2, 1923, in New Matamoras to Virginia Richards. He attended Matamoras United Methodist Church. He was a retired self-employed building contractor. He was a Boy Scout leader and Little League coach. He was a member of the New Matamoras City Council and the Washington County Health Board. He was commander of American Legion Post 378 in New Matamoras. He enjoyed farming in his retirement. He is survived by his wife, Vera Doan Amos: two sons, David Amos and his wife, Sandy, of New Matamoras and Alan Amos and his wife, Lori, of Westerville; and four grandsons, Chad Amos and his wife, Holly, and Jason Amos, all of New Matamoras, and Matthew and Jeff Amos, both of Westerville. He was preceded in death by his mother, who died January 31, 1978. Services are at 2 p.m. Sunday at Hadley Funeral Home in New Matamoras with the Reverend James Schoonover. Burial is in Matamoras Cemetery. Friends may call from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday at the funeral home.

Andears, Thomas R. 'Uncle Buck'  

                Woodsfield, Ohio - Thomas R. "Uncle Buck" Andears, 54, of Wood Street died Sunday (November 24, 2002) at his home. He was born February 12, 1948, in Akron to Thomas and Louella Pickens Andears. He was a Vietnam veteran. He was a former truck driver, a member of the North Coast Motorcycle Club and a former elder of Buchanan Presbyterian Church. He is survived by four sons, Thomas Andears, James Andears, Bradley Mathers and Harley James Andears, all of Akron; three daughters, Amber and Brandy Moody, both of Woodsfield, and Tonya Edgell of Columbus; his mother of Lewisville; three sisters, Patricia Andears of Lewisville, Betty Moats of Lewisville, and Connie Riggs of Akron; and five grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his father and one brother, Danny Andears. Graveside services are at 11 a.m. Saturday in Friendship Cemetery in Lewisville. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 South Paul Street, Woodsfield, Ohio. Source: The Marietta Times, Wednesday, November 27, 2002.

Anderson, Andrew Martin

                Lewisville, Ohio - Andrew Martin Anderson, 36, of 48391 Ohio 145, Lewisville, died Friday (January 10, 2003) near Lewisville. He was born July 3, 1966, at Fresno, California, to Martha P. Meek Miller and Clifford Martin Anderson. He was a foreman for a power line construction company in Sanford, North Carolina. He was a Baptist by faith. He was an avid fisherman and hunter.

He is survived by his wife, Lori Rininger Anderson, whom he married on September 21, 2000; one daughter, Kayla Anderson at home; his mother of Lewisville; one sister, Shelly Vasquez of Santa Ana, California; and one brother, Thomas Anderson of Spring Lake, North Carolina. He was preceded in death by his father; and his stepfather, Henry B. Miller. Services are at 6 p.m. Tuesday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Keith Jones officiating. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. Friends will be received from 3 to 6 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home. Source: The Marietta Times, Monday, January 13, 2003.

Anderson, Bradley K. and Rana A. Swallie

                Announcement is made of the engagement of Rana A. Swallie to Bradly K. Anderson. Parents of the bride are Chris Swallie of Columbus and Linda Swallie and Jim Robinson of Barnesville. Parents of the groom are Kenny and Ruth Anderson of Barnesville. The bride-to-be is a 1998 graduate of Barnesville High School and Basic Military Training. She received a bachelor of science degree in exercise physiology from Ohio University in 2001 and a master of science in physical therapy from Wheeling Jesuit University in 2003. She is employed as facility director of Marden Rehabilitation in Woodsfield, and will receive a doctor of physical therapy in May 2005 from Wheeling Jesuit University. Her fiance is a 1996 graduate of Barnesville High School. He received associate degrees in mechanical and electrical engineering in 1998 from Belmont Technical College and a bachelor of organization leadership and development from Wheeling Jesuit University in 2004. He is employed at Ohio Coatings Co. in Yorkville. An October. 9 wedding is being planned.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Elmer Stimpert, in 1977; three sons, Robert and Richard in 1957, and Donald in 1971; one brother, Albert Anderson; and four sisters, Iva Lumbatis, Emma Jackenheimer, Isadora Steed and Mary Marshall. She is survived by one son, John Stimpert of Washington Court House; one daughter, Ruth E. Wittenbrook of Lewisville; one half sister, Gladys Girton of Zanesville; three grandchildren; and four great grandchildren. Friends will be received at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield from 7 to 9 tonight and from 9 a.m. Tuesday until the time of the services at 2 p.m. Tuesday. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery at Woodsfield. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Methodist Church, Lewisville, Ohio, 43754.

Anderson, Mr. Earl and Miss Dorothy Tucker

                On Saturday, April 22, 1961, Miss Dorothy Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tucker, Woodsfield, Route four, was united in marriage with Earl Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Anderson, Lewisville, Ohio, Route 1. Minister J. V. A. Traylor performed the double-ring ceremony at seven oclock in the afternoon at his home on Eastern Avenue, Woodsfield. The bride chose for her wedding a green taffeta street-length dress with which she wore matching accessories. Her corsage was of yellow carnations. Her bridesmaid, Mrs. Dale Kilburn, wore a Brown suit with which she wore White accessories. Her corsage was also of yellow carnations. Serving Mr. Anderson as best man was Dale Kilburn. Mrs. Anderson graduated from Green Local high school, Laings, Ohio, class of 1954 and Mr. Anderson graduated from Lewisville high school, class of 1956. The newlyweds are now at home to their friends at the William Tucker home on Woodsfield, Route four.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, April 1961.

Anderson, Marjorie

                Marjorie B. Anderson, 88, of New Martinsville, West Virginia. Died Tuesday, October 12, 2004, in Wetzel County Health Care Center, New Martinsville. She was born April 5, 1916, in Clarington, Ohio, the daughter of the late Frank and Carrie E. Arn Stauffer. She was a 1936 graduate of Salem High School, Clarington, a retired employee of Herrick's IGA, New Martinsville, a member of the Zion United Methodist Church, Clarington, and a 50 year member of the Order of Eastern Star, Littleton Chapter 117 of Hundred, West Virginia. and Chapter 50 of New Martinsville. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Willis G. Anderson in 1964, four brothers and five sisters. Surviving are several nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends on Friday, 4 to 8 p.m., at Grisell Funeral Home & Crematory, 751 Third Street, New Martinsville, where services will be held on Saturday at 11 a.m., with Reverend Richard Wilson officiating. Eastern Star services Friday at 7 p.m.

Interment will be at Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville. Memorial contributions can be made to Zion United Methodist Church, in care of-- Bonnie Logston, 48450 Cain Ridge Road, Clarington, Ohio 43915.

Anderson, Myra Lorena (nee Morris)                              

                Zanesville, Ohio - Myra Lorena Anderson, 96, of Zanesville, formerly of Graysville, died Tuesday (June 24, 2003) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center.  She was born March 7, 1907, near Graysville to Andrew Spencer Morris and Zelda Pearl Kinkade Morris. She was a member of the Pleasant Ridge Church of Christ for more than 80 years. She married Cars Alexander Anderson on September 1, 1927. He died April 13, 1983. She is survived by two daughters, Mrs. Ray (Rosalie) Coss and Mrs. Fred (Ruth) Woodyard, both of Zanesville; one son, Willis Anderson and his wife, Betty, of Graysville; two sisters, Mrs. Orpha (Mildred) Vess of Lower Salem and Mrs. Ray (Ethel) Sullivan of Columbus; eight grandchildren; 15 great-grandchildren; and three great-great-grandchildren. In addition to her husband, she was preceded in death by her parents; and six brothers, William Alfonzo Morris, Earl Morris, Edward Morris, Isaac Morris, Maywood Morris and an infant brother. Services are at 2 p.m. Friday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home at 100 South Paul Street, Woodsfield, with Minister Harold Kinney officiating. Burial is in Pleasant Ridge Cemetery near Graysville. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Thursday at the funeral home.

Source: The Marietta Times, dated Wednesday, June 25, 2003.

Anderson, Ralph H.

                Caldwell, Ohio - Ralph H. Anderson, 84, of 9000 State Route 78, Caldwell, died at 7:25 a.m. Wednesday (October. 27, 2004) at the Summit Acres Nursing Home in Caldwell. He was born May 16, 1920, near Summerfield, a son of the late Oliver and Lula May Okey Anderson. He was a retired diesel mechanic for the Central Ohio Coal Co. in Cumberland, Ohio; a member of the Reinersville Methodist Church; a U.S. Army veteran of World War II; a member of the Disabled American Veterans; a former member of the Sharon Lodge 136, Free & Accepted Masons; and a former member of the Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite, Valley of Cambridge. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his wife, Edna Virginia Powell Anderson, on October. 5, 1981; four brothers, John, Harry, Robert and Roger Anderson; and two sisters, Mildred Anderson and Grace Williams. Surviving are a companion, Myra Van Fossen of Caldwell; four sons, Clyde (Violet) Anderson of Oak Island, N.C., Larry (Katie) Anderson of Caldwell, Francis (Bea) Anderson of Caldwell and Donald (Susan) Anderson of Beverly; two brothers, Delbert Anderson of Cumberland and Richard Anderson of Caldwell; one sister, Nellie Clark of Caldwell; 10 grandchildren; several great-grandchildren; one great-great-granddaughter; and several nieces and nephews. Services will be held at 2 p.m. Sunday at Brubach-Watters Funeral Home, 202 Main St., Summerfield, with Frank Love officiating. Burial will follow in Mount Ephraim Cemetery, Mount Ephraim, Ohio, with full military graveside rites by Caldwell VFW Post 4721 and Belle Valley American Legion 641. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday at the funeral home.

Source: Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, November 4, 2004

Anderson, Robert

                Robert M. Anderson, 71, of Shadyside, died Saturday, October 9, 2004 at his home. He was born at the family homestead of Lawrence and Beulah Fankhauser on Cain Ridge near Clarington, Ohio. He was the son of the late Hazel Stauffer Anderson Johnson and stepson of Leroy Johnson. Bob was a retired Mine Foreman from Consol's Quarto number four mine at Powhatan Point, Ohio. He was an avid hunter and an enthusiastic Ohio State football fan; a member of the American Legion Post 228 of Powhatan Point and the Royal Order of the Moose in Woodsfield. He was a United States Marine Corporation, veteran and a friend of the Saint John's United Church of Christ at Powhatan Point. Surviving are his wife, Marlene M. Johnson Anderson, a son, John R. Anderson and his wife, Sandy of Hilliard, Ohio; a daughter, Jodi R. Forni and her husband, Jerry, of Beallsville, Ohio; a very special granddaughter, Jessica Forni; a sister, Betty Mellott of Clarington, and a favorite nephew; Thomas Mellott and his wife, Debbie and their two daughters, Megan and Abby, all of Clarington, Ohio. Family and friends will be received at the Bauknecht- Altmeyer Funeral Homes & Crematory, 3900 Central Avenue, Shadyside, on Tuesday from 4 to 8 p.m., where services will be held on Wednesday at 11 a.m., with Pastor Alex Tychkin officiating. Interment in the Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to the Shadyside Emergency Squad, 4210 Central Avenue, Shadyside, Ohio 43947 or the Saint John's United Church of Christ, 51736 German Ridge Road, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942. Online condolences may be offered to Bob's family at www.altmeyer. com

Source: The Times Leader, Martins Ferry, Ohio. Published: October 11, 2004.

 

Anderson, Rosalie B. and Forrest Burkhead

                Married: December 25, 1877. Source: Monroe County marriage records.

 

Anderson, Rosena Faye (nee Hogue)           

In everybodys garden a little rain must fall

Or Lifes sweetest, fairest flowers

wouldnt grow and bloom at all;

And though the clouds hang heavy,

 so heavy, Oh my friend,

Im sure that God who sends the shower

will send the rainbows end.

                Rosena Faye (Hogue) Anderson, only daughter of Leland R. and Mary (Cline) Hogue, was born near Woodsfield, Ohio, on March 28, 1928, and departed this life on December 22, 1951, being at the time of her death, 23 years, 8 months and 24 days of age. On January 10, 1948, she was united in marriage with Alexander D. Anderson, of Newark, Ohio, and to this union was born one son, Danny Lee Anderson. Besides her husband and little son, she is survived by her parents, Leland R. and Mary E. Hogue, and three brothers, Private First Class Larry R. Hogue, of Fort Hood, Texas, and Bobby and Keith Hogue of the family home in Newark, Ohio; also a large number of other relatives and friends. While yet a small child she was baptized at the Bracken Methodist Church near Lewisville, Ohio, and remained true to her faith in God and the Church. She was always in Church as long as her health would permit, and always took an active part in the work. Rosena was educated in the Monroe County schools, having attended school at both Lewisville and Woodsfield. She moved with her family to Newark, Ohio, seven years ago, where the remainder of her life was spent. Rosena was gifted with a wonderful personality and many will remember the numerous occasions when she sang in the Church and at many other religious meetings. From childhood, she was gifted with musical talent, which she greatly enjoyed as long as her health would permit.  She was always ready and eager to help those who were less fortunate than herself. She was especially helpful to her loved ones and in the home. Her going leaves an emptiness that this world can never fill. She will not only be missed in the immediate home, but by a large number of relatives and friends to whom she had endeared herself as the wonderful person that she was. Three years ago she was stricken by the fatal disease, which slowly but surely, sapped her life away. All that loving hands and medical skill could do, was done, but to no avail, and she quietly slipped away from this world of pain and sorrow to an unseen world to us. Short funeral services were held at the home in Newark, on Wednesday morning, December 26, at 9:30 oclock with the Reverend H. E. Doyle, of the Pine Street C. U. Church, officiating, after which the funeral cortege left for the Bracken Methodist Church near Lewisville, where final services were held at 2:00 with the Reverend Fontella Linn, of Lewisville, officiating. Interment was made in the Bracken Ridge cemetery by the Criss Brothers Funeral directors of Newark.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, December 1951.

Andes, Henry

                Henry John Andes, 93, of Clark Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Monday, October 4, 2004 at his home. He was born December 31, 1910 in Castle Shannon, Pennsylvania, a son of the late Jacob and Theresa Leich Andes. Henry was retired owner/operator of the Community Market, Powhatan, and was a member of Saint John Vianney Catholic Church and a 4th Degree Knights of Columbus member. In addition to his parents, Henry was preceded in death by his wife of 61 years, Helen Rose Doria Andes on April 17, 2000; a son, John Datti, a brother, Philip Andes and a sister, Mary Zanin.  Surviving are three children: Henry Joseph Andes and his wife Sandee of Pataskala, Ohio, Sylvia Brown and her husband, Kenneth, of Maitland, Florida, Helen Ann Koff and her husband, Charles, of Rosemont, Florida; four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Friends will be received on Thursday, October 7, 2004 from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m., and from 8:30 a.m. until time of mass at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan. Funeral Liturgy with Mass will be celebrated on Friday at 10 a.m., at Saint John Vianney Catholic Church with Monsignor Gene Mullett as celebrant. Burial will follow in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio. A vigil service will be held on Thursday at 3 p.m., in the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to Meals on Wheels. Online condolences may be made to Henry's family at www.altmeyer.com

Source: The Times Leader,  Martins Ferry, Ohio. Published: October 5, 2004

 

Andrews, Alta S. and Peter Bever

Andrews, Bertha (nee Claus)          

                Woodsfield-Mrs. Bertha Reich Andrews, 78, of Sycamore Street, died at 4 p.m. Saturday (October 1, 1966) in Barnesville General Hospital where she had been a patient for two days. Born December 19, 1887, near Monroefield, she was a daughter of Charles and Margaret Claus. She was a member of Woodsfield United Church of Christ. Surviving are her husband John Andrews; two sons, Vernon Reich of near Lewisville and Arthur Reich of near Miltonsburg; a stepson George Andrews of Barnesville; seven grandchildren; several step-grandchildren; and seven great grandchildren. The body was taken to Bauer-Turner Funeral Home where friends may call. Services will be held at 2 PM (Day Light Savings Time) Tuesday at the funeral home with Rev. George Corbitt officiating. Burial will be in Miltonsburg Cemetery.

Source: The Times Recorder, Zanesville, Ohio, Monday, October 3, 1966.

Ankrom, Cora J. (nee Jackson)       

                Woodsfield, Ohio - Cora J. Ankrom, 74, of the Monroe County Care Center died at 4:16 p.m. Wednesday (April 23, 2003) at the center. She was born August 31, 1928, near Woodsfield to Jerry and Ida Baker Jackson. She was a homemaker and a Baptist by faith. She is survived by two sons, Richard Ankrom and his wife, Connie, and Paul Ankrom and his wife, Rita, all of Woodsfield; one daughter-in-law, Sandra Ankrom of Woodsfield; and several grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her husband, Hila F. Ankrom; two sons, Hiram Ankrom and Earl Ankrom; her parents; one brother, Ole Jackson; three half sisters, Margaret Daniels, Martha Koontz and Estella Griffith; and one half brother, Lewis Jackson. Services are at 11 a.m. Saturday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with the Reverend Earnest Hulsey officiating.

Burial is in Neuhart Cemetery near Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.

Source: The Marietta Times, dated Thursday, April 24, 2003

 

Ankrom, Demaris (nee Carpenter) 

                Demaris was 78 yrs. old, born about 1852 in Ohio. Both her parents were born in Ohio. She was 25 yrs. old when she married. She could read and write. She lived with her husband, William M., and son, Hila F., and granddaughter, Goldie D. Breeden, in Seneca Township, Monroe Co., Ohio.

Source: 1930 Ohio Census.

                Demaris Ankrom (nee Carpenter) Died: December 21, 1932.

Source: Monroe County, Ohio, death records. Volume number: 7089.

Certificate number: 73939.

Ankrom, Earl Foster, Sr.    

                 Earl F. Ankrom, Sr., 51, of 34177 MIltonsburg-Calais Road, Woodsfield, died Friday (January 26, 2001) at Barnesville Hospital, Barnesville. He was born April 4, 1949, in Barnesville, son of Cora (Jackson) Ankrom of Woodsfield, and the late Hila Foster Ankrom. Mr. Ankrom was a graduate of Skyvue High School near Graysville. He was a former construction worker and a former welder for Watt Car and Wheel in Barnesville. He was a U.S. Army veteran, having served during the Vietnam War. He was preceded in death by an infant brother; an uncle, Ole Jackson. He leaves his wife, Sandra I. (Anderson) Ankrom, whom he married June 17, 1972; a daughter, Mrs. Fred (Amanda) Shaw of Woodsfield; three sons, Earl F. (Jaime) Ankrom, Jr. of Stafford, Timothy R. (Emanuela) Ankrom of Sardinia, and Arlis C. Ankrom of the home; two brothers, Richard (Connie) Ankrom of Woodsfield, and Paul (Rita) Ankrom of Florida; three grandchildren; several nieces and nephews. No calling hours will be observed. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, is handling the arrangements.

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, January 28, 2001.

Ankrom, Nora, nee Flanagan

                Bethesda-Nora Ankrom, 86, of 811 Hutchinson Drive, Barnesville, died Tuesday morning (July 30, 1985) at the home of her daughter on Quaker City R.D. 1. She was born October 26, 1898, Washington, Paennsylvania, daughter of Sylvester and Eliza Otten Flanagan. Mrs. Ankrom was a retired employee of Barnesville Hospital and a Protestant by faith. She was preceded in death by her husband, R. Purley Ankrom, who died in 1978; three brothers, Tom, Phil and Harry; three sisters, Emma Kirkbride, Lucy Conner and Lottie Tarleton. She leaves a daughter, Mrs. Francis (Kathleen) VanNess of Quaker City R.D. 1; two sons, William of Quaker City R.D. 1 and Harry of Canton; four grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Friends may call 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Thursday at Kelly-Kemp Funeral Home in Bethesda, where services will be 1 p.m. Friday with Rev. Steve Manko and Reverend Thomas Dooley officiating. Burial will be in Friends Cemetery, Quaker City. 

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, July 31, 1983.

Anthony, Timothy George and Gloria Sue Scarbro      

                Daiton and Susan Scarbro, of Rinard Mills and Timothy and Lewada Anthony, of New Matamoras, announce the engagement of their children, Gloria Sue Scarbro nd Timothy George Anthony. The bride-to-be is the granddaughter of Raymond Gene and Pauline Harmon, of Rinard Mills and Edith Brooks, of Woodsfield. She is a 1994 graduate of SkyVue High School. She is employed as a secretary at Wood County Aviation, LTD in Williamsburg, West Virginia and as the assistant manager of the Alderes Motel in New Matamoras, Ohio. The prospective bridegroom is the grandson of George Clutter, of New Matamoras. He is a 1995 graduate of River High school and Swiss Hills Vocational School. He is a riverboat pilot for Johns Towing Service, Inc. of Shippingport, Pennsylvania.

The wedding ceremony will take place at 4 p.m. May 27, 2000, at Grace Baptist Church in Devola, with custom of open church to be observed. A reception will follow at the American Legion in Marietta, Ohio.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, February 3, 2000.

Antill, Wesley       

          Wesley Antill, 78, of Woodsfield, died Saturday morning, November 12, 1966, at seven oclock, in Mercy Hospital, Canton, where he had been a patient several days. Born near Graysville, March 17, 1888, he was a son of Joseph and Susan Johnson Antill.  His wife preceded him in death. Surviving are two sons, Homer Antill and Harry Antill, both of Woodsfield; a daughter, Mrs. Hazel Litten, of near Woodsfield; nine grandchildren; five great grandchildren; a brother, John Antill, of Hiawatha, Kansas. Funeral services were held Monday afternoon at two oclock in the Bauer and Turner Funeral Chapel, with Minister John Hamilton officiating.  Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.

 

Antler, Herald G.

Antler, John W.

                Born: July 1, 1869, Franklin Township. Parents: Samuel and Mary Antler

Source: Monroe County courthouse birth records.

 

Antonik, MIchael T. and Patricia K. Landefeld

                On October 31 Patricia K. Landefeld became the bride of Michael T. Antonik. Minister Harry Summers officiated at the double ring candlelight service at 7 p.m. at the Woodsfield Church of Christ. The bride was given in marriage by her parents. Her gown was of quinta featuring a Queen Anne neckline trimmed in lace and pearls with pleated skirt and fitted sleeves capped with lace. Her hat featured a chapel veil with a veil and bow flowing the length of the chapel train. She carried a white Bible given to her by her parents with a bouquet of rust daisies and baby's breath. Mrs. Kim Bauer served as matron of honor. Misses Marla Zitko, Debby Withun, Debbie Cook and Nancy Hamilton served as bridesmaids. Brandi Griffin served as junior bridesmaid and Jennifer Landefeld as flower girl. The gowns were rust color with ivory lace trim. The junior bridesmaid and flower girl wore dresses similar to the bridesmaids made by Beverly Landefeld. They carried chamber lanterns encircled by rust and brown daisies and baby's breath with lace streamers. Rick Kasper served as best man. Ushers were Gene Freeman, Steve Antonik, Scott Antonik, and Skip Bauer, Junior usher was Davey Landefeld and Darin Landefeld served as ring bearer. Singers for the wedding were Brenda Matthews, Carol Fliehman and Brian Christman. A reading of 1 Cor.; 13 was done by Duane Landefeld. A reception followed the ceremony at Woodsfield Grade School. Serving as hostesses were Bonnie Egger, Shirley Masters, Barbara Poulson, Goldia Chaplin and Arlene Summers. The bride carried out the tradition of something old, borrowed, a gold necklace with a pearl, which was made from an earring that was her Grandmother Egger's, something new, a pair of pearl earrings, a gift from her husband, something blue, a garter and a penny in her shoe, given to her by her uncle. The rehearsal dinner was held October 29 at Mehlman's in St. Clairsville and was hosted by the parents of the groom. Their parents are Mr. and Mrs. Lester Landefeld of Route 3, Woodsfield and Mr. and Mrs. William Antonik of Old Winding Hill Road, Bellaire. The new Mrs. Antonik is head nurse of the Progressive Care Unit at the Ohio Valley Medical Center in Wheeling, West Virginia. Mr. Antonik is a technical representative for the Xerox Corporation. Following a wedding trip to Canaan Valley the couple is residing at 63447 Old Winding Hill Road, Bellaire.

Source: Monroe County Beacon, November 16, 1981.

Archer, Abraham

                Abraham Archer was born in 1815 in Noble County, Ohio. Died: August 29, 1847, Miltonsburg, Monroe County, Ohio. Burial: Saint Michaels Cemetery.

Parents: Michael and Rhoda Grandon Archer. Married October 8, 1835 at Saint Marys Church, Temperenceville, Belmont County, Ohio to Mary L. Sterritt. Born: June 13, 1815 in Ohio. Died August 29, 1896, Rock Bluff, Cass County, Nebraska. Burial: 8 MIle Grove Cemetery, Nebraska.

 

Archer, Allie (nee Dowell) 

          Mrs. Allie Archer, 87, of Caldwell, died Saturday night, May 13, 1967, at 11:30 oclock in Summit Acres Nursing Home at Caldwell.  She had been ill several months.  She was born June 7, 1879, in Noble County, a daughter of Charles and Mary Dowell.  Mrs. Archer was a member of the Caldwell First Methodist Church and of Amazon Chapter No. 30, Order of Eastern Star.

Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. Gladys Scott, of Mansfield; three grandchildren; five great grandchildren, and three sisters, Mrs. Leota Curtis, and Mrs. Lily Curtis, both of Summerfield, and Mrs. Madge Davis, of Caldwell.  Her husband, Amos Archer, died in 1931, and a daughter, Mrs. Opal McElfresh, died in 1958. Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon at one oclock in the McVay Funeral Home, at Caldwell, with the Reverend DeForest Winner officiating.  Burial was in the Olive Cemetery.
